Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer to the question is “D”.<n><n>### The population is concentrated<n><n>### in apartment buildings.<n>### population density can affect<n><n>### the location of a city.<n>### Most people live in<n><n>### apartments in a city<n>### population density of a city<n>### can influence the number of<n><n>### apartmetns that are built.<n><n>###<n><n>### 10<n><n>#### **FINAL**<n>#### **ANSWER** <n>* <n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Input:#37 was at one time known as the area code for what city?<n><n>### Demo:<n>#37 is now Arizona's area code.<n><n>### #37 was at one Time Known as the _Area Code_ for what City<n>#37 was Arizona's area code (the first area code in the US that began with a "3" that was not a 0)<n><n>### #978's area code is in what state<n><n>#978 is Massachusetts State<n><n>#### 978<n><n><n>### Input#36 was at one time known area code<n><n>### Demostration:<n>#36 was Pennsylvania's area code. It is now in Maryland. The first of the 20 digit area code is always going to be a "3" and the second is always "6".<n><n>### <n>#36  <n>#Area  Code  <n>#Pennsylvania<n><n>### 9<n><n>### Input:-Is area code known as a NORTHERN AREA code for Maryland 94138  <n><n>### Demosntration:<n>```<n>94138  is Maryland area code<n>9 is one of the northern areas of Maryland<n>Northern is one of the areas of Maryland.<n>```<n><n>### Answer:Yes<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demonsration<n><n>4169  is Toronto area code<n>0 is Toronto North area<n>9 Toronto North area code<n>4160  Toronto North area code<n><n>##### 0<n><n>### Demotion<n><n>### InputArea code 992

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:The only devices that require a cable are the television. For the desk cabinet and radio shack, the cable isn't a necessity. A cable is required for a television, not radio shack, cabinet or desk, hence C is the answer.

Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n><n>### Response:		A<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question by filling the blank using the word that best replaces the question and replace with the correct symbol.<n><n>### Input:(3!)(7 + 3) in expanded form.<n><n>### Rationales:3 is written in expsnos form and it is multiplied to 7, resulting in<n>7 x 3 = <<7X3=21>>21<n>1 in the form of an exponent indicates multiplying by 1, which is 1 x <7, = 7>7 = 7<n>Thus 3! + 3 = 3 x (7 + 1) = <<3x7+3=21>><n>Thus its Expanded form is 21<n>#### 21<n>Answer: 21<n><n>### Instruct:Use the correct mathmatical symbol to complete the sentence.<n><n>### A:<n>The expression 5 + 14 x 2 + 9 x 1 can be simplified using the following strategy: first add all the numbers in the expression, and then simplify any numbers you can. <n> <n>### Rationals:<n>First add the first expression: 5+14x1+9x1=<<5+14+9=28(exponent =1)>><n>After the above addition, the result is<n>28<n>Then, you combine 28 with the next expression in its parenthesis, which you add it with the one that you did before<n>28+14+9<n>Thus, the expression can be simplified to 28+14=<<28+14==42(exponent==2)>><n>Further, the expression 42+9 can be simplified according to the above strategy, resulting in 42+9==<<51>>51.<n>Hence, the whole expression can be simplified to<n>51<n>#### 51<n>Answer: 51<n><n>### B:<n>Express 22 x -1 in the form a + b.<n><n>### Response<n><n>22x-1 = 22*-1 = <<22/-1==22>>22x-1=-22<n><n>#### -22<n>Answer: -22<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The man was eating lunch, but rushed when he looked at his watch, why did he rush? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. When doing the task, think hard.<n>2. Read all the question.<n><n>3. Underline the key words.<n><n>4. Read the question or task again<n><n>5. Read the question again.<n>6. Then answer the question.<n><n>## Input:In a class of 22 students in grades 8-12, there are 10 boys. The ratio of the number of boys to girls is 19 : 17. What percentage of students wear watches?<n><n>## Rationales: Input:<n><n>What I did is I subtract 17 from 22.<n><n>Ratio:  19 : 1  <n><n>So I will get 9<n><n>Ratio: 50:7  <n><n>So I get 7<n><n>Rationales:  <n><n>In a class of 51 students, only 8 are wearing watches, What percentage of students wear wathces?  Input:<n><n>The ratio of boys to girls is in favor of boys. Then the number of boys is 9. In a class of 100 students, there are 75 girls and 25 boys. What percent of the students are girls?<n><n>To find the value of N, I write 100 down.<n><n>I subtracted 25 from 100, so my answer will be 75, and my value of N is 75.<n><n>### Rationale for Input : In a class of 60 students, 20 are wearing watches and 10 are wearing jewelry. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The second answer, The students should study about the question:<n>How many men who fought in the civil war.<n>Why? Because the answer should be: men counted in the school test! And because the students should study first the question : Who are the men that fought in the war?<n>The second answer:<n>The third answer:<n>The students study last the question: How did the American civil war end?<n>How many people died in the American civil war?<n>The students will ask these questions if<n><n><img src = "../images/test2.jpg" width="250" height="120"><n><n>The student knows the third question!<n>Because they should study the war who ended when the student finish the civil war test<n><n>###  Answer:C<n><n>###  Input: John, a schoolboy, has a new jacket, a new cap, a new glove, and a new shoelace. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What's it called when you have seen something through an eyepiece? Answer: 1<n><n>So 1 in 3 means a = 1 / 3 = <<1/3=0.33>>0.33<n><n>For 2,005 keys: 0.332005 = <<0.33*2005=660.5>>660.5<n><n>For 3,001 keys: 660.52001 = <<660.5*2001=1321.0>>1321<n><n>For 3000 keys: 1321 + 3 = <<3+3=6>>6 + 3000 is 3003<n><n><n><n>So  a^3006 equals 1.<n><n>Or in other cases<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>So if you have 3000 and you get 2000,<n>the chance of key 3,006 being correct is 1<n><n><n><n>## Input:Joe made a large meal. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where must one wear a white shoe? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What place of work might you find a hairpin? Choices:  A: hair salon B: hair of woman C: barber shop D: pincushion E: woman's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Choice: E<n><n>### What is the value of 1^2*1^2 *1^2?<n><n>### Input 1: What is the value of (7 + 8)^2* (3 - 5)^2 * (3 + 2)^2?<n><n>## Solution:<n>First, we have to find the absolute value of (x-y) for x not equal to y.<n><n>Absolute value of (x-3)(y-1) : (x-y)<n>=>|x-3|*(y-1)<n><n>Then we have to take the absolute value of each component's x and y, and multiply them.<n><n>=>(|x-3|*(|y-5|*(|3+2|*(|x-1|*(|7+8|*|x-1|*|(3+(x-1))-5|*|3-1|*|x-3|))<n><n>Answer: 1^2 = <<1^2=1>><n><n>1^2*1 = <<1^2*1=1^2>><n><n>1^3 = <<1^3=1>><n><n>Therefore the answer is 1 * 1 * 1 = <<1*1*1=1>><n><n>Input: Find the value of (x^3) * (x^2)<n><n>Input: Find ( (x*1)*(x*1)*(2.0*x) )<n><n>Input: Find all possible products of 3/2, 1/1, and 2/4<n><n>Answer: (2)/(4) is 1/2 because 2 x 2/4 = 2*1/4 = 2/4 => 1/2<n><n>Therefore, the answer is 2*1/2*1 = <<2/2*1=1>>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Explain Your Answer:<n>The old man was retired, and he likes to do crossword puzzles every morning. So, his main job is to relax.<n><n>### Submission Instructions: The form fields will contain the answer choices. Choose option A or B.<n>Input: The old man was retired and like the simple things, he will do crossword puzzle? Choices: A: you're booring B: pass time C_ _____ D: mentally challenging E: win<n>Answers: A<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: How many students live in a house?<n>Rationales A: Every home needs to be in a specific location.<n>B: Students might live in a house with other kids, too<n>C: In a house, the students will live too, not in the classroom<n>D: In a house, there is just one floor, so all the members of the family live in a house too<n>E: Students will probably not live in a house by choosing the home,<n>Rubi: No, you will choose the home for yourself, not the home where you live.<n>Rationales E: A home is somewhere you can relax.<n><n>Rationales E is correct because student home will make a place for them to rest because in home there is room for everything you're using or needs it.<n><n>Answer:<n>C<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Instuctions: Answer the following true/false question<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: A good student always is in class. <n><n>### True/False Response:<n>True, because a good student who are doing homework, will do homework even if the teacher were not on class, it means that no matter the teacher don't go to class the good student will still be in class.<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The man was cleaning clothes for his date, what was he looking to achieve? He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: <mark>dress yourself</mark> if you don’t mean beer.<n>B: <mark>take a shower</mark><n>C: <mark>get dressed</mark><n>dress your dress or her dress and then drink beer or have beer on a train.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: Dress yourself and drink beer if possible.<n><n><n>### Input<n>Which one of these pairs of numbers is greater?<n><n>### Demostration<n>The third step in working with decimals is to compare two decimals and to determine which is greater. To determine the greater of two decimals, remember to follow the following steps:<n><n>1) Write each number in the order in which you want it—so, for example, the first digit of "0.2", which is "2", comes first in the order of the numbers.<n><n>2) Subtract the second decimal place from the third decimal place. If this is a positive number, then the first number is greater; if this number is negative, then the second number is greater. The second part of this will be "number one" and "number two".<n><n>3) Subtract the third decimal place from the fourth decimal place. Continue doing this until you get to the last decimal place, which is going to be either the first number or the second number, depending on which was greater in the previous step. If the last decimal places of the two numbers are the same, then the numbers are equal. If the last decimal place of one number is one greater than that of the other number, the first number is greater.<n><n>4) Write down the sum of the two numbers and move the decimal point two places to the left. If the number after doing so is greater than the number before doing so, then the resulting number is greater than the previous one; if the number after doing so becomes less than the number before doing it, the previous one—the one before the two-step—is the greater of the two.<n><n>#### 34<n>Answer: 36<n><n>### Input : Which pair of numbers is the greatest? 3.13 3.87 3.51 2.65<n><n>### Response<n>The most significant digits in each number are the ones that go in front of the decimal point. The next-most-signific

Choices:  A: suitcase B: filing cabinet C: computer D: desk drawer E: cloud<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>A: A suitcase keeps physical things, not digital files.<n><n>B: A filing cabinet keeps hard copies of paper things and not digital files.<n>C: A computer is used to create and edit digital files.<n><n>D: A desk drawer is used to keep everyday items, such as keys, paperclips, and rulers. It can also be used to hold a USB drive and store digital files.<n><n>E: The cloud is one place to keep digital files. The Internet is not a place to keep things. Even though the cloud and the Internet are both digital, a cloud can be used to keep things while the Internet cannot.<n>#### E<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions:What is the difference between a set and a group? Choices: 1) Set is an unorganized collection. Group is a collection with organization. 2) Set is a specific collection. Group is an unspecific collection. 3) Set has a finite number of objects. Group has an unlimited number of objects. 4) Set has only one element. Group has more than one element. 5) Set has a beginning and ending. Group has no beginning or ending.<n><n>### Response(s): I'll list what I found.<n><n>#### 2) Set (Collection): is a limited, specified list.<n><n>#### 5) Group (Pigeon-holing or Cluster): is a set of elements.<n><n>#### 4) A set contains an infinite number of numbers, while a group contains only a set’s prime members.<n><n>#### 1) Set is a collection with all of its members.<n><n>#### Answer: 5<n><n>### Response (s): <n><n>#### 3) A set has a finite number of members, and a set may have no members. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is a sign that you might not be living soon? Choices:  A: growing older B: reproducing C: shuddering D: perspiration E: palpitations<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>Growing older<n>```<n>A: <<Growing older>><n>```<n>#### B<n>reproducing<n>```<n>B: <<Reproducing>><n>```<n>#### C<n>Shuddering<n>```<n>C: <<Shuddering>><n>```<n>#### D<n>Perspiration<n>```<n>D: <<Perspiration>><n>```<n>#### E<n>palpitations<n>```<n>E: <<Palpitations>><n>```<n>### The final answer should be<n><n>- A + B or B + A<n>- B + E or E + B<n>- C + D or D + C<n>#### B<n>Reproducing+palpitations<n>```B> Palpitations + reproduction ```<n>::: tip<n>Write the answer on your paper, but do not show your work. The answer will appear after the check box.<n>:::<n><n><div class="grid grid-cols-1 grid-rows-4"><n>  <div class="col-span-1">A</div><n>  <div class='col-span-6'><n>    B <input type="checkbox" label="palpitations" checked /> reproducing <input type="checkbox"> shuddering <input type="checkbox"></div><n>  <input type="checkbox"/><n>  <input type= "checkbox"/><n></div><n><n><div class='grid-rows-3 grid grid-cols-1'><n>  <div class = "col-span-1-">C</div><n>  D <input type="checkbox"><br><input type="checkbox"><input type="checkbox"><n>  <input type = "checkbox"/><input type ="checkbox"/><n></div><br><n><n><style><n>  td {background: white;}<n>  th {background: white;} <n></style><n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following short answer question.<n><n>## **Demonstration:<n>You buy a bottle of 300 mL wine. Each time you mix the wine with one can of beer, 100 mL of the wine evaporates. You drink a 355 mL can. How many cans of beer must you drink to make a 1 L bottle if the beer takes more or less than 1 L to produce, if A or B is true
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is a great, but non-specific, overall benefit of exercise? Choices:  A: good health B: heart attacks C: relaxation D: rest E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>  C: heart attacks

C:  What is the average of 28, 39, and 47?<n>D: What is the median of 44, 19, 45, and 1?<n>E: How long does it take 39 minutes to run this math practice exam?<n>#### Question2:<n>A: The total amount of money that can be generated by investing 40% of his $3,500 paycheck equals:<n>B: How much should John charge  for a book  ________ ? $16 will be a little pricey.<n>C: How much did Sari spend on groceries compared to  ________  dollars?<n>#### Question3:<n>A: How much of a percentage difference is between $17 and $18?  ________ <n><n>### Rationales<n>### Question1:<n> <n>The answer is B, 10, because when you take 33 and subtract 19 from it leaves 14, and when you subtract the difference by 10 you get 4 <n><n>### Question2:<n> <n>The choice C is the answer to this problem. The other choices do not involve the answer to the question. The answer is $14.80 <n><n>### 6. Question3:<n> <n> <n>The choice B is the correct answer to this problem. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:If I have to keep track of how much oxygen there is, where am I? Choices:  A: air B: water C: earth D: space shuttle E: tunnel<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: air<n><n>### Rationale:<n>You are in air because air is made up of molecules. Each one has two oxygen atoms.<n><n>### InputChoices:<n><n>### A: air B: space shuttle<n><n>### Rationales:<n>You are in space because space is made up of moleculess and atoms only. Each one has only one oxygen atom.<n><n>### B: space shuttles C: earth D: tunnel<n><n>## #Rational:<n>You are in earth because earth is made up of molecualre and atoms only. Each  has only  one oxygen atom.   <n><n>### <n>Input :  A person earns $1.76 per hour and regularly works eight hours per day. If they work ten days in a pay period, how much money will they earn?<n><n>## #Rationale:<n>The person earns 1.76 x 8 or $14.48 a day. Ten days is equal to 10 x 8 = 80  so $80.54.<n><n>### Response Choices:<n>Rationale:<n>Input: The value of an empty basket is 30 ounces. When 83 pennies are put into the basket, the value of the basket increases by 148 ounces. How many pennies were put into the basket?<n><n>Answer choices:<n><n>### Rated 1: 9 ounces<n><n>```<n>Rational for choice 1:<n>The value of an empty basket = 30 ounceed per ounce because 30/1 = 100 ounces = empty basket.<n>Value of the basket = 148 + 30 = 178 ounce<n>178 x 16 ounces per pence = 2872 pennies.<n>```<n><n>```<n>Rated 2: 87 pennies<n>```<n><n>```  <n>Rationale for choice 2:<n>Value of an empty basket  -30 ounces because 30/88 = 3.5 = empty basket.<n>Basket value = 148 - 30/83 + 83 = 998 - 4 =9/6

Choices:  A: arrogate B: retain C: embrace D: smile E: engage<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Answer: E: engage<n>To _____________ is to start a fight or contest, in which you accept the challenge from another person or group. In response to something done by another person, you can ______________. -to engage B: retainC: embrace D: smilE: engage<n><n>#### Answer: D: smile<n>To retile is to put something, such as a covering or surface onto the outside of a building or machine to make it smarter or better. -to retile B: retainC: embracD: smileE: enagageg<n><n>#### Answer: E : engage g<n>Rearrange these letters to spell the 0.2 answer.<n>AZDZJBCD<n>### Birthday:<n>Enter Birthday Date:<n>4.11.22<n>The digits 41122 are converted to the month of 0.4 (20). In order to convert a date to a month, you have to take the number of days for that given month. There are 31 days in January. The number of days for April is 30, and the number of days for February is 28. Using the birth date you input in the field, we are converting to a month and then subtracting a factor for year, in order to get the month. Using this method, you subtract the year, then the month, then the day. For example, if you want the year for a birth date, you would take the date and subtract the year; then convert the leftover numbers to a birth month. If you entered a birth date of Novemver 2, 2005, you would take November, subtract May, and the digits left over would be a 13. 912 is three months and three years. The digit 2 in November is two months plus two years. Using this method, the digits we end up with are 8011.<n>The final step is that we will flip the digits. This is because, we have numbers in front. 8,0,1, and 1, so to find our month, we need to flip the second and fourth digit. These flipped digits are 1,8,0, and 1, this shows us the month of 08. We have to add 08 to the

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What cuisine is joked about eating small dogs? Choices:  A: backpack B: dog show C: chinese food D: french E: good hands<n><n>### Response:		<n>

One of the doors to the hallway is not visible when the hallway door is open. When the hallway door is closed, the other door leads to one of the laundry facilities. Assume that the apartment is numbered 1 through 10, that the hallway is numbered 2, and that each of the laundry rooms is numbered 0 through 3. Write a program to determine which laundry room apartment 6 is closest to.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The master control for the Tardis is where in the main room? Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A,B,C,D,E are all an option but the answer is main office.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>The Master Controls or the Console Room, is the bridge of the TARDIS and the place where the TARDIS is most often manipulated.<n><n>#### #1 Choices:A:<n><n>* Nuclear power plant: The Doctor has been known to use a nuclear power plant to get the TARDIS going, and has used it to power himself, the Eleventh Doctor demonstrated this, turning the radioactive material in several control rods on a nuclear power plant into an energy source for his sonic screwdriver so he could repair the TARDIS (and heal Clara).<n><n>#### #2 Choices:B:<n><n>* Center: The heart of the TARDIS.<n><n>#### #3 Choices:C:<n><n>* Basement: The first Doctor said he was not in the basement on the TARDIS. In the season 2 finale, "Doomsday", the Doctor said she was in the basement.<n><n>#### #4 Choices:D:<n><n>* Main Office: Clara referred to this location as "The Main Office" when traveling on the TARDIS between Earth-That-Was and Trenzalore. In "Hell Bent", the Eleventh Doctor called this the command center, indicating that this is where the real controls of the TARDIS are located, rather than in the TARDIS console room. <n><n>#### #5 Choices:E:<n><n>* Bowel of the ship: The Tenth Doctor referred to the TARDIS as a "Great big ball of wibbly-wobbly, timey-wimey...stuff."<n><n>### Exercise:<n>Write a response in the box provided.<n>Use complete sentences.<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:There was a show on television about a ranger who loved flowers, but the next day it was about a gardener who also loved flowers.  It was a what? Choices:  A: countryside B: anthology C: dull read D: state park E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>There was a show on a television about a ranger, but the next day, it about a gardner? Which one was correct?<n><n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input and Demonstration<n>The only answer that is gramatically correct is D.<n><n>### Input<n>A: countryside<n>B: anthology<n>C: dull read<n>D: state park<n>E: surface of earth<n>### Rationales:<n>D: state park was correct because a ranger worked in a park and a gardner work in a park<n><n>### Answer:<n>D<n><n>### Input <n>1. A person walks 14 m North and then 10 m West.<n><n>```python<n>def walk(north, west):<n>	"""returns total distance from point (0,0)[north, west]<n>	"""<n>	if north > 0:<n>		if west > 0:<n>                	 return north + west	<n>		return north<n>        return north - north - 2 * north # <n><n>```<n>```python<n>a, b = walk(5,3)  # 5 + (-3) 17<n>print(a, b)<n>```<n>			<n>### Answer: 2, 10<n><n>### Instructions and Demonstrations:<n>The output of `walk(5,3)` should be 2 and 10.

Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Jet lag is a physiologic disorder caused by air travel. Jet lag is caused because of the discrept between the circadian rhythms. When flying, we are in one time zone, but when we land, we are in another time zone.<n><n>Source: Patterson, M. (n.d.). Disorders caused by air travel. Retrieved October 27, 2018, from https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3156104<n><n>#### 5417<n><n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Instructions:Use the information in the table below to answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Table:<n>| Name | Age |<n>| :-: | :-: |<n>| Richard | 20 |<n>| Hurley | 14 |<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: When Hurley is 19 years old, will he be 21 years old?<n><n>Rationales: Richard is twenty years old and Hurley is fourteen years old<n><n>|20 + 4| - |4| - |1| - |5| <19+5= <-19->19<n><n>|5| - |3| <-20-3=<-20->20<<20>>20+20-3= ->23<n><n>Answer: Yes<n><n>Input: Which mathematician developed the Fermat Number? How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What would you put furniture on top of? Choices: 1: 34 2: 6 3: 57 4: 28 5: 98<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input: What would you put furniture...<n>Rationales: F(floor) would be the last choice on the list even though F, R and D are pronounced the same way. <n>Answer: D<n><n>Input: What would...<n>Rationales : P(parent's home) would be last, even though P is spoken the same way as F and R because there is a silent P in Floor.<n>Answer: C<n><n>Input: What...<n>Rationales Floor is pronounced with an L sound. P is silent in the last 2.<n>P(parent's home), which is the 4th answer would be last.<n>Answer: A<n><n>Input: What....<n>Rationales Apartment is silent at the end. "Floor" "Roof" "Apartment", which end with P (parent's home) "neighbor's house". <n>The same rule applies to roof and neighbor's house.<n>Answer: B<n><n>Input: What....<n><n>Rationales F(floor) is silent at the end<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>Input: What...<n>Rationales F is silent at the end, and the last character is a P (parent's house)<n><n>Answer: D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:You can read a magazine where while waiting for your transportation on rails to arrive? Choices:  A: train station B: bookstore C: newsstand D: waiting room E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>Select the letter (the A through E) that should fill into the answer blanks.<n><n>The letters should be in alphabetical order as follows:<n><n>A, B, C, D, E<n><n>If you are lost in your thinking about how to complete this instruction, close everything else, take a moment, and start from the top again.<n><n>Answer the questions on one line. Do not use the back slash (\).<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The man needed balls of cotton, where should he look? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? Choices:  A: stripes B: seat belts C: breaks to help stop D: tires E: radios<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A <n><n>### Input<n><n>Is the number of candies you get for each color of M&M’s different in two bags if there is _any variety_ candies in each bag?<n><n>### Response<n><n>No<n><n>### Input <n><n>Is it possible for a computer to be human-like and have emotions? <n><n>### Response <n><n>Computers can be human-like, and they do, in fact, have emotions. In order to do so, for example, they can use emojis. <n><n># **Solutions**<n><n>---<n><n># **1.**<n><n>```python<n>#!/bin/python3<n><n># Problem Statement<n><n>def answer(answers):<n>    # Answer<n><n>    # for each question<n>    for i in answers:<n>        # get the number of correct answers<n>        if sum(answers(i)) == i:<n>            return i<n>        <n># call function<n>answer(['A', 'D', 'E', 'D'])<n>```<n><n># **2.**<n><n>```Python<n>#!/bin/Python<n><n># Problem Statements:1. Find the remainder of 252 mod10 (3).<n># Answer<n><n>def remainder(n,div):<n>    <n>    <n>    if div==0:<n>        return n%10 #prints answer<n>    <n>    else<n>        return remainder(n,div-1)<n><n># call function <n>print(remainder(252,10))<n>```

Choices:  A: joke B: humor C: frightened D: fight E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: humor (Humor can mean that you can make people laugh. It usually means that you can entertain someone, so if they are expecting something, and make it more funny, it is surprising)<n><n>### Input<n><n>Echo: "Please, will please you, sir, repeat after me."<n>Pablo: "Please me, sir, do I have to repeat after you? It is rather rude to keep repeating yourself when I know that I don't need to repeat the same thing over an over like you do."<n>Echo: "Yes, Pablo my boy, you do it."<n>Following Pablo's reply, what is the relationship between the two people?<n><n>### Rationales<n>1. In Pablo's speech, he tells Echo to repeat after him.<n>2. If the person repeats after him, the relationship between the two is parent.<n>3. Echo tells Pablo to repeat after him so the relationship between the two of them is not parent.<n>4. The relationships between the two people is brother and sister<n><n>### Correct answer:<n>Correct answer<n>Answer: Echo and Pablo are Brother and sister<n><n>## 175:<n>Input: Echo yells, "Hurrah!"<n>Following Echo's utterance, what kind of action does Pablo do? Choices: A: he asks Echo if he hurrahs for him as well. B: he repeats after Echo C: he yells, ​"Hurray!" D: he hurrahs for Echo. E: he yells, "Hooray!"<n>Input: Hurrah!<n>Choice: Hurrahs for Echo<n><n>Answer: Hurrahs for her<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The man took 3 hours every morning for grooming, what is the likely result with his job? Choices:  A: tardiness B: looking good C: injury D: vacation E: neatness<n><n>### Response:		Answer (E)<n><n>The man took three hours to groom. Grooming includes many things such as shaves and haircuts. So, he could be looking good and neat. But looking good can mean that he is late to work because he spent so long to look good and not late to work. So it's D that stands for vacation.<n><n>### Input::What is the largest prime factor of 285? Choices: 1: 13 2: 19 3: 25 4: 29 5: 59<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If 285=13 x 22<n><n>or<n><n>If 289=(29-1)=28<n><n>then<n><n>285=1 x 22 + 28<n><n>the largest factor is 28<n><n>289 is bigger than 28 but 28 is not bigger than 28<n><n>### Input&nbsp;:John’s age is one less than seven times Melissa’s age. Ten years ago, their sum of ages was 66. What is John’s age? Choices:  (1) 27 (2) 28 (3) 33 (4) 34 (5) 53 A: 53

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		A refusal<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>#### A: Question<n><n>:question is a verb, we could also write questioning, but that is not the right answer that is refusing<n><n>#### B: Dispute<n><n>:dispute is a word that describes some type of disagreement, if we dispute someones answer we are disagreeing with it, but that is not what happens if the reference refuses<n><n>#### C: Deny<n><n>:deny is a verb, we can write deny, or denying, but if a reference decides to deny you, then they are not confirming or denying you, because you are not asking for confirmation, you are asking for the reference to confirm, and when confirming your answer<n><n>#### D: Contradict<n><n>:contradict is a verb, we write contradict, or contradicting, but we need the opposite of confirm not contradict<n><n>#### E: Refuse<n><n>:refuse is the right answer it is not a verb, but it is a noun, that is when you use the word refuse, you are not refusing people if the reference refuses you, they are still confirming you<n><n>### Input : An accounting test was given. Someone said, "How many times did the second question make me cry?" A) 1 B) 2 C) 3 D) 4<n><n>### Response : B<n><n>Rationales :<n><n>#### A: 1<n><n>1. That is correct you multiply 4 x 3 and you get 12, so the second question would make you cry 12 times because you cried while you were reading and while you were answering and while you were reviewing, and when you thought you answered the question correctly and then you got it wrong<n><n>#### B: 2<n><n>2. The second question makes you cry 2 times because you cry when you read and when you answer and when you remember why you were taking the test in the first place<n><n>#### C: 3<n><n>3. The second question makes two times as many cries because you cry when you remember why you're taking the test, you cry when you read the question, and you cry when you answer it<n><n>#### D: 4<n><n>4. The second question makes 4 times as many cries when you think you answered it right

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where are seats most likely bleachers? Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E<n>Input:Where is George Lucas, the famous director, from? Choices: 	A: Ohio B C: California D: New York E: Boston<n><n>E<n>Input:$400 is equal to how many ounces?<n>Choices: 	A B: $1 pound D: $2.5 ounces<n><n>$400=1 pound because 400/2.5 = <<400/25=16>>16<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>###<n><n>### Answer:<n>$400 = $1 Pounds<n><n>Because 400/$1= $400/$1 =<< 400/1= 400>> 400<n><n>400<n>

Choices: A: bike shop B: car dealership C: pizza place D: gas station E: taco place<n><n>### Response :If you were to buy a gas station, this would likely be the most cost effective since most people have bikes and need gas for their vehicles.<n>Because gas stations are a popular and reliable place, this option is wrong. <n>Likewise, because gas stations are the most profitable, option D is correct. Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		A B C D E<n>### Rational:I don't know<n><n>Input: The salon has appointments that are scheduled at one-hour intervals. One dog is groomed for one-and-a-half hours. What happens to the next appointment?<n><n>Demonstration:<n>In 1 and a half hours it is 1 and a half x 1 which is 30 minutes<n>Rationales:<n>In 30 minutes it is 30 minutes ÷ 60 because there is a 24 hour day<n><n>\### Input: How much more would you get for the carpet if you pay the salesman 10 cents per square foot instead of 2 cents? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Sarah thought that she had been home all evening.  That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question.<n><n>## Input: Write a two-dimensional array with 6 rows of six boxes. Indicate a box, and write the number in each box in the array. Your answer needs to be an array, an if statement, and an else statement all in one.<n><n>### Response<n><n>```javascript<n>let A=new Array(6)<n>for (var j=0; j<6; j++)<n>  for (let k=0; k<6; k++) A[j][k]={}<n>A[0][0]={2,'2-10':2,2,'2-20':2, 2,'3-10':2}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>Filling in the correct answer is important in a situation that has a direct impact on a person’s quality of life. It’s important to understand the questioner’s request: In order to be successful in school, a person must have many qualities that contribute to successful learning. First, they must have a positive attitude to the entire process of learning. To have a positive attitude they should expect a fair amount of challenges, but also expect to learn new things, and enjoy these experiences. Next, they should have confidence in themselves. When they are feeling underconfident, they can make sure they don’t underestimate themselves, or they can ask for help. Finally, they must be passionate about at least some subject matters. When they don’t have passion for school, they need a way to get out of the rut of feeling apathetic. They need to think about the value of learning in school.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>I believe that an appropriate response to my requester would be an explanation. An explanation is a description of what you did in the past, as well as your reasons for doing it. It is a chance for the one being asked the question to give the interrogator information about their past actions, but also why they did it the way they did.<n><n>A way to answer a question that gives you a list of things that are desirable is to say which things they do have. A list shows that the questioner is already on the right track, but if they have done all of these things, they should be in the right mindset to complete the task they asked for. It is a good way to support the requester without having to say more or less. A response that contains less is not a valid response, because although it may be true, it is giving a lack of support for the request. A response that contains more is an over-response. It contains unnecessary information, and gives the requester many things to think about. This sort of response is good to avoid, but if you have little details you want to share, you can still be concise.<n><n>### Improvement:<n>A way to improve my response is to include less details for an over-response. Giving the interrogator more than they need is a difficult task, especially with a limited amount of time. If you include too many details without understanding the requester, you will be giving them more information than they

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		<n>Downtown<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following two choice question.<n><n>#### 1<n>Downtown is a place to buy a lot of different things and a place to find many places to eat, so it is the correct answer<n><n>#### 2<n>Shopping center is a place to find places to buy many types of things<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Downtwon is a place to buy any type things, whether it be shopping or eating.<n><n>Downtown means the part of town with many buildings.<n><n>Shopping center can be found in a lot of places in the city that are all downtown.<n><n>Shoppings are built in shopping malls.<n><n>There can be as many as 1000s.<n><n>1<n>Shopping center in downtown:<n><n>#### 1234<n>Answer: Shopping center<n><n>## Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question with one of the following:  A: yes B: possibly C: maybe D: no E: probably F: definitely<n><n>## Rationales:<n>It is possible that Pablo read a couple of extra books,<n><n>It is definitely false.<n><n>Pablo did not read $3 worth of books.<n><n>It is definitely possible.<n><n>It is probably false.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: <n><n>## Instruction:Answer the following multiple-choice question. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a desk normally occupied by a young person? Choices:  1A: 0  2A:1 3C:1 4D:2 E:3<n><n>### Rationales:<n>For n=1, the sum of the products will be 1 x 1 = <<1*1=1>>1<n>For n=2, the sum of the product will be 2 x 1 = <<2*1=2>>2<n>Therefore, for n=1, the product will be 1 and for n=2, the product will be only 1 (since 1*1 = <<1*2=2>>2 and 1*2 = <<1*2>1>>1 ).<n>Hence, for every n > 1, 1 must be included.<n><n>### Answer for (n <= 1):<n>    Input: Which of these sets has the highest product: {1 1 }, {3 1 1 }, {2 4 2}, {6 1 8}, and {9 3 6 6}? Choices:  D:1 B:4 E:6 C:12<n><n>## Rationales:<n><n>      In order to calculate the product of one of those numbers, you need to multiply each set by the respective number.<n><n>      { 1 1 } = 1 1 * 1 = <<1 1=1>>1 which is just 1.<n><n>      {3 1 2} = 3*1*2 = <<3*1*2=6>>6<n><n>      Therefore all products except {2 4 1} are equal to 6.<n><n>      {  5 * 2 * 2 * 3 } = <<5*2*2*3=370>>370<n><n>      {  8 * 6 * 6 * 2 } = <<8*6*6*2=2160>>2160<n><n>      Therefore, product with highest number is 370. <n><n>##

Choices:  A: fairgrounds B: friend's house C: space shuttle D: oven E: microwave<n><n>### Response:		The vehicle that food is freeze dried before is on the space shuttle. An example of how food is made to last on the space shuttles is by making it very dry and freeze dried. If it were not freeze dried, it would mold. If you are taking it to a friend's house, you would not want it to have mold on it. Another example would be that if you freeze dried it then it could not grow mold. Choice C or answer (b) does not make sense for the space shuttle because that would mean putting it inside the space shuttle to dry, but since it is dry it would be hard to fit in the space shuttle (too bulky). Choice D or answer (b) could not be right because since it is freeze dried, you would use the oven to heat it back up. Choice E or answer (d) could not be right either because a microwave cooks the dish and since it is no longer wet, it would be inedible.<n><n>### Input::In what country is the highest and longest railroad in the world found?<n>A: Australia B: Russia C: England D: Scotland<n><n>### Response::In what country is a the highest and longest rail road found? Answer (a), Australia. Australia has one of the most highest railways, Mount Kosciusco. Mount Kosciusco is 7,400 feet high, but a railway, the Kosciusco Tramway Railway, goes all the way up to Mount Kosciusco. This railway is very long too.<n>### Input-:The fastest sneaker maker on earth, Adidas’ superstar is the hottest selling shoes for kids in the United States.<n><n>### Response-:Answer choice (A) is not a fact. I think that Adidas are the most popular, but Converse is still the most expensive and sought sneaker.<n><n>### Answer:C<n><n>### Input:-The difference between 90 and 68 is the same as what plus 14?<n><n>### Response:-The difference between 70 and 68, plus 14, is the same as the addition, 34
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What does someone chatting with friends do when they hear a joke? Choices:  A: giggle B: lie C: laughing D: chuckle E: smoke<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>What does someone chatting to a friend do when they hear a story? You have a choice between wearing shin guards or not. Your best friend won’t talk to you if you wear thigh highs or shin guards. How do you determine this list?<n><n>###Programmer<n>Write a program that, after inputting, prints out the Fibonacci Sequence. The Fibonacci sequence starts with 0 and 1, then 1 and 1, then goes on with the next two numbers with each number that follows the sum of the two numbers that came before it. For example, if we entered the Fibonacci sequence as 0,1,1,2,3,5 then the sequence of numbers it would print would be 0,1,2,4,7.<n><n>###Program<n>Write a program that sorts a list of names.<n><n><n><n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. Choices:  A: leg B: garment C: torso D: body E: road<n><n>### Response:		 (C)<n><n>### Justification: The correct answer is torso according to article's context and vocabulary.<n>- torso: (noun) the upper part of the body between the neck and hips.<n>- body: (noun) a group of people seen or considered as a unit, the mass or size of the body or a specific feature or condition of it.<n><n>In this scenario and the use of "so his" modifier or referent, writer means "taking the hit" or "being hit", so "the arm or what wouldn’t take the hit" can mean either the right arm or the left arm. This is a subjective statement, so it is the subject 'right/left arm" that would avoid taking the hit, not the body as a whole.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Instructions: Choose the correct response below.<n>### Demo instructions: He walked back to his seat and tried to fall on my shoulder so my arm would take the hit.<n>### Demo response: C: >>He walked back to his seat >>  I didn't try to fall on my shoulder, or <<I didn't try to take the hit on >>my shoulder, or <<I wasn't trying to fall on my shoulder just to avoid your >>screw-up, okay?<n>I was trying to take the hit on my shoulder.<n>He walked back to his own seat and tried to fall onto his shoulder so the blow would take the hit on his body, not mine.<n><n>### Input and Output:<n><n>### Input (Source):He stepped back. He had no choice but to see his mistake. His head fell off his shoulders.<n>### Input (Teresa's words):Choices: A: head B: arm C: torso D torso E: road<n><n>#### D<n><n>### He<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a hairbrush along with bandages? Choices:  A: drugstore B: hospital C: bedroom D: car E: house<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rationales: D: In the car<n><n>### Choice:  C: House<n><n>#### A: Drugstore<n>Answer: C: House<n><n>### Explanation: D: The hospital<n><n>### Response Explanation: Rationales: Drugstore:  B: The hairbrush must be an ordinary, everyday commodity that is bought without a visit to a medical specialist, e.g. a hairbrush could be bought in a drugstore.<n>D is wrong. The hairbrush must not be bought as medicine for some illness related disease:<n><n>#### B: Hospital<n>Hairbrushes are not bought as a medicine in a hospital. If you are sick and your hairbrush breaks, you buy a new one online or in a drugstore. Hairbrushes are bought in drugstores and as medication in hospitals or in specialized stores. Hairbrush for sick people are bought in specialized stores and the medication is not directly given in a hospital to the patient – but to the doctor (or nurse) who then gives it to a patient. A normal person do not go to the hospital nor do a specialized stores to buy a hairbrush.<n><n>Hairbrush in a hospital for normal people: In a hospital a normal person will get a new hairbrush only if your normal hairbrush stops functioning. If you have a hairbrush that can’t function or is broken, you can not buy a new hairbrush in the hospital. You will get a new brush either if it is provided by the hospital as a part of your medicine. This is not usual for normal hairbrushes. You can also bring your own hairbrush to the hospital – as long it fits within security policy, e.g. that no sharp objects are brought to the hospital. But a hairbrush is not considered a sharp object – in general. You can also buy your own hairbrush in the specialized online stores; then you are allowed to bring it to the hospital.<n>Hairbrush for sick patients: A hairbrush not for normal people is bought in the hospital at the ward or at the discharge room – if you’re going home early. The patient do not buy it him- or herself.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would someone be likely to store a double edge razor? Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: Pocket<n>

The solar system has the sun at the center and the planets that revolve around the sun are called the solar system. If a human wants to be near their solar system, they will go to outer space. A place near the sun is called the space shuttle. This is also related to outer space, so going to a space shuttle is the best choice.<n>The main reason why humans want to sit in a coffee shop is because they love coffee. He read 150, then he got 1.5. Then after reading his book, he went to the shop and bought $ 15 worth of book and had $ 3 leftover<n><n>then 150 - 1.5 = 148.5<n>Pablo would have earned $148.50 and he bought candy worth $15.<n><n>Pablo’s mother paid him $1.50 for each page and Pablo read 15 pages, so his mom would have paid him $ 22.5.<n><n>### How many pages did Pablo read in total?<n>```<n>128 - (22.5) - 1 = 12 - 24<n>```<n><n>```<n>12 pages<n>```<n><n>### How much candy did Pablo buy with his $ 3?<n>```<n>3 * 150 = $ 450<n>```<n><n>```$ 450 > $ 15 <n>```<n><n>```3 * 15 = 45<n>```<n><n>```45 * 3 = 135<n>```<n>Pablo spent 135 cents and he did not spend the three last cents.<n><n>**3 * 15 + 1 = 52 cents**<n><n>```<n>Pablo bought candy in the store that was 15 dollars.<n>That is 15.00 Dollars.<n>So 52 / 15 = 3.46.<n>```<n><n>So Pablo spent $3.46 and he still had 1 cent left with him.<n><n><n>### The two sides were able to EVEN reach tentative agreement<n><n>### What does  reach tentative agreement mean?<n><n>A. To accomplish a task
