You can find it in<n>the health department.<n><n>The drawer also does not have pamphlet regarding disease and ailment. But you can find it in <n>the health department. <n><n>Lastly, the mail box also does not have pamptlets regarding disease and ailments. But you<n>can find it in the health department.<n><n>---<n><n>Input: You are looking for your best friend when an elephant suddenly barges into the room. Your friend is under an elephant. What should you do?<n>Rationales Choices:<n><n>#### 1: Stay still<n><n>#### 2: Jump<n><n>#### 3: Crawl<n><n>#### 4: Shout his name<n><n>#### 5: Wave your arms<n><n>#### 6: Tie a rope around him and drag him away<n><n>Answer: <n>1. Stay still, the elephant moves when you move<n>2. Jump, you can reach the other side<n>3. Crawl, you can go around the elephant<n>4. Shout his name, you can tell the elephant to bring him out<n>5. Wave your arms, you can tell the <n>elephant to bring him<n>6. Tie your rope around him and pull him out, you can drag him out<n><n>Demonstration: (Crawl)<n>---<n>Demonstration (Crawl) : Your friend is located at the end of the elephant's trunk. You can crawl under the elephant'<n><n>####  D: Drag him out<n><n>Answer: drag him out<n>1: stay still<n>2: jump<n>3: crawl<n>4: shout his name<n>5: wave your arm<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What animal produces milk? Choices:  A: supermarket B: pig C: cow D: refrigerator E: store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A: supermarket<n>Answer: A, supermarket<n><n>Answer: A,<n><n>#### B: pig<n><n>#### C: cow<n><n>#### D: refrigerators<n><n>#### D:<n><n>#### E:<n><n>B:<n><n>#### B<n><n>Answer: B, pig<n><n>#### E: store<n><n>Answer: store<n><n>#### A: Supermarket<n><n>#### B: Pig<n><n>#### C : Cow<n><n>#### D: Refrigerate<n><n>#### D: Store<n><n>#### E :<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The janitor got his pail out of where? Choices:  A: wishing well B: kitchen C: hardware store D: garage E: utility room<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Rationales:Because Garage is the correct answer it is E<n><n>### Instructions:  Give the response that is correctly spelled.<n>### Demonstion: <mark style='background-color:green'> <n>### Input: Which one of the following words begins with a silent <b>h</b>? Choices:  F: Heron B: Hail C: Hind D: Hume E: Honer E: Hut<n><n>### Rationale:<mark style='background- color: green'><n>### E: Honer. Because H is a silent 'h' in  hunt<n>### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input<mark style='background -color:green'>  Which one of the following sentences contains a verb in the imperative? Choices:  B: Is the bird in the nest? B: Are the nests in the tree? C: Is the bird in nest? C: Are the birds in the nest?  D: Is the bird in a nest? D: Are the birds in a nest?<n><n>### Response<mark style='background color:green'> <n>B<n><n>### Racionale<mark style='backgroundColor: green'><n>##Because the bird in the nest is an imperative sentence it is B<n>##B<n>####B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input  Choices:   <b>A:  He wants to build the bridge out of concrete</b> <b>B:  He wants to built the bridge out of concrete </b> <b>C:He wants to build the bridge  out of concrete </b><b>D:  He wants to buil the bridge out of concrete<n><n>### RATIONAL:<n>### The words built and out should be capitalized because they are the beginning of a sentence<n><n><n>### Input : If you divide the number 110 by 2, which digit in the remainder shows which remainder does it show? Choices:  4 2 1 9 8<n>### Response<b>: 8</b><n>### Rational<b>4,2,1,9,8</b>:<n>### Because there is no remainder<n><n>### Input <mark style='backgroundColorGreen'>:  Choose the

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>The correct answer here is : D<n>```<n><n>### Rationale:<n>```<n>In my opinion, the answer (D - Fire house) is the correct answer because it is the only line that is near the road. We can also consider the distance that we are taking to access it, by that, it is a distance that is taken to get to some place.<n>To answer it:<n>1. We are near a road where people stand on a line, now we are considering whether there is a distance that separates us from that line, if not, then the line must be near water fountain, military base, apartment, fire house or bus stop.<n>2. We have eliminated A: water fountains, B: military base, C: apartment, D: fire house, E: bus stop.<n><n>There is no line which is on the road that is near some road because it is away from a path. This is the conclusion of our steps:<n>1. Are we near a road? yes : We are in a car.<n>2. Is there a distance between us and the line? : yes.<n>3. Are there any people near water fountains, military base, aaprtments, fire house, bus stop? : We are at the fire house, so we need to go to a bus stop so that we can continue our journey. <n>```

This indicates that you have never been to a desert but have been in the Army.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:She was bad at dancing, so what basic skill did the instructor teach her? Choices:  A: euphoria B: rhythmic movement C: music D: moving body E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		Basic question.  A:  Euphoria<n><n>In the question, the word "bad" must mean at a low level. So the correct answer is the opposite of her low ability at dancing, she was able to learn the skill that she was supposed to be bad at, which is she learns how to do euphoria movement.<n><n>### Note:<n>We must be sure to write the question backward. <n>This is the correct way to analyze any word question. <n>When the instructor says, “She was bad at danciing,” we must understand, “She was not good at dancing.” <n>So when asking a word question, ask yourself, “What is the opposite or what is not good at this.”<n><n><n>### Input<n>In the following expression, is there a way to reduce what is after the “-” to a factor?<n>(X ÷ Y)+Z ÷ 3<n>Rationales: Yes, we can multiply by X by Y.<n>Yes, we can remove the ¾<n>So the answer is no.<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Input :<n>2009 – 1327 + 2010 ==?<n>Rationales: 673 20,000 – 180.372 + 2020 – 0.285 = 20,052.44<n><n>#### 20,065<n>Answer: 20,076<n><n># 69<n><n>### #69<n>#### 68<n>Answer: 68<n><n>How to Analyze the Word Question<n><img src="images/How to Analyze Word Question.jpeg" /><n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Why would someone confess to committing murder? Choices:  A: guilty conscience B: fear C: go free D: problems E: find god<n><n>### Response:		B, D A: guilty conscience<n><n>### Response explanation: <<GUILTY CONSCIENCE>>GUILTY CONS<n><n>D: problemes<n><n>E: find god<n><n>A: guilty consience<n><n>B: fear<n><n>C: go free<n><n>### 1.<n><n>### 2.<n><n>### Input:(248 - 88) + 47<n><n>### Response:(160 - 88) 62 + (88 - 42) 46<n><n>### 62<n><n>### 46<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is something you do  in a bank? Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n><n>### Response:		<n>My guess is E is the answer because you put things like money in the bank. This is a good one.<n>

This produces a sum equal to 24; the number of boys<n><n>#### 24<n>Answer: 24<n><n>### Demaindon:<n>Input:You are walking in the park and there were six different pigeons on the grass. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Too many people want exotic snakes.  The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		The answer is Choice D) Pet Shops<n><n>### Demotion:<n>Pet shops are businesses that sell, and take care of, animals. <n>The animals could be: fish, hamsters, dogs, cats, turtles. <n>People might take exotic snakes to these places, because the exotic snakes might eat, and be taken care of, there. <n>It is not likely that most pet shops in North America would carry exotic snakes because of the high price of an exotic snake, and because of the danger the snake might pose to the pet shop worker.<n><n>### Discrimination:<n>Exotic snakes are not "driven" to be carried by pet shops, so you cannot say it is the answer.<n><n>### Clarification:<n>A pet shop is a place where people can take the animals they have. One example of an animal being taken there is an exotic snake. Because of this, people might decide to take their snake there to be taken care of. <n>Another place where people can take their animals is the outdoor,  but the exotic snakes do not live outdoors, so they are not "driven". <n>Another place that people can take their animals too is a Ditch, but the exotic snake would just be sitting there. <n>Another shop, north america, would just be too risky for the owner of the shop.<n><n>Exotic snakes that are not kept inside of a pet shop and are not driven there.<n><n>### Rules:<n>There are some rules that are needed for this task.<n><n>1. Answer the question correctly.<n>   1. The RFP will not accept an incorrect answer. <n>   2. The RFP will reject an incorrect answer.<n>2. Provide an accurate response that properly completes the request. <n>   1. The task can be rejected if the response is not accurate. <n>   2. Providing an accurate answer to a question will likely increase the chances of the task being accepted.<n> <n>### Examples:<n>Example 1<n><n><img src="../img/fantasy_questions_0.png" class="center my-2" alt="Sample"/><n><n>## Instruction:Answer the question.<n><n>## Demonstration:

Choices:  A: brain problems B: laziness C: get fat D: headache E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		<n>1) A is correct because the word choice in the sentence was incorrect<n><n>### Comments:<n>#### Input:<n><n>---How to solve:<n>```python<n>ans = "E" if 'get fat' in line else 'A' if 'brain' in line else 'B'<n>```<n>```python<n>if 'get fat' in sentence:<n>    ans = 'E'<n>else:<n>    ans =  'A'<n>```<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>You had a great day shopping for school supplies. A train traveling at 80 kilometers/hour leaves Miami and travels due north. A passenger travels to Toronto in 16 hours. Three hours later, the passenger goes to Toronto to Toronto. Then, the train leaves from Toronto to Seattle. The passenger gets on the train at the same time as the train’s departure in Toronto. How many more hours will it take the train to reach Seattle after the passenger gets on board?<n><n>Inputs: The distance from Miami to Toronto 2 __________ kilometers,<n>The distance from Toronto to Seattle 2 ___________ kilometers. Then. how many more hours does it take the train to travel to Seattle?<n>Output answer: ___________ hours.<n><n>2- Inputs: The time in the spring is 3:40 p.m. in the spring. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is eating too much dinner likely to result in? Choices:  A: tiredness B: living longer C: stomach ache D: illness E: acid reflux<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Living longer by eating more<n><n>### Input<n>Your father’s birthday is March 11 of every year. In one year, the number of years since the day before his birthday will be greater than the number of years since his birthday. What is the day before your father’s birthday?<n><n>### Response<n><n>March 12<n><n>- March 14 is 1 year after March 12<n>- March 12 is 1 year before March 14

However, a person who follows the announcement will arrive back close to that destination. Which of the following statements best describes the bus that leaves here?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rationales: You only need if you follow the announcement or disobey to decide which bus you should take. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:WHat do cats get into when they are ripping things apart? Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n><n>### Response:		<n>I don't know it is not in your assignment.<n>### Rationales: <n>You said, "dog's mouth", but that is not in the assignment.<n><n>### I don't know<n>#### <n>Answer: <n><n>### Input  : How can you make a group of boys sing on key? <n><n>### Response  : I don’t know how to sing in a group, my voice is not good<n>#### <n>Answer  : <n><n>### My Response<n>1. What are you gonna do? I don’t know (I want a teacher)<n>2. How was it? I was on a plane flying to Hawaii.<n>#### <n>Answer<n>My answers<n>1. How is it? I was on my way to the theater with my friend. (I was in the city)<n>2. How do you like it? It was very nice (I have never met my friend before in my life)<n>#### <n>Answer : <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What might you feel after doing housework for hours? Choices:  A: anger B: not boredom C: stress D: boredom E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>There is an assumption that boredom is the opposite of stress.  Stress would not be caused by boredom, but it may cause boredom.  Boredom is defined as the state of being “stuck” in a routine.  Boredom can also be caused by being unable to solve a problem.  That makes you feel “stuck” in the situation.  If your house work is too much for you, you might feel stressed before feeling bored, not after feeling bored.<n><n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:You can hear testimony of how spirituality changes lives when you do what? Choices:  A: go to church B: appear in court C: watch soap operas D: paying attention E: go into court<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Demanstration The word you need is go to church <n><n>---<n><n>```python<n>answer1 = 3 # <n>answer2 = "C" # <n>answer3 = "D" # <n>answer4 = "A" # <n>answer5 = 15 # <n>gold_age = 13 # <n>diamond_age = 11 # <n>answer = ( gold_age - diamond_age ) # <n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would there be many people sitting in chair and listening to religious speech? Choices:  A: auditorium B: office C: synagogue D: confession E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Fixed Points:<n>```<n>A: <<Auditorium>><n>B: <<Office>><n>D: <<Church>><n>E: <<Church>>	<n>```<n><n>#### Unfixed Points:<n>```	<n>C: synagogue<n>```<n><n>We can find all the points on the circle.<n>The only correct answer is option D.<n><n>### Input<n>A: <<Insurance>><n>B: <<Professional>><n>C: <<Betta>><n>D: <<Home>><n>E: <<Income>>	<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Fixed points (Cant find):<n>```<n>A: none<n>B: none<n>E: none<n>```<n><n>#### Fixed point (Cant find): A: <<Insurance Policy>><n>B: <<Home Insurance>><n><n>#### Fixed pointers:<n>```	<n>E: none<n>D: <<Home Insurer>><n>```<n><n>#### Correct answer:<n>```	<n>A: none<n>```<n>B: <<Home>>	<n>```	<n><n>We can find the fixed points by using the information and finding the points on a circular path.<n><n>This one is simple.<n><n>#### Example<n>[https://math.stackexchange.com/users/67903/p-d](https://math.stackexchange....) [https://math.stackexchange...](https://math.s..m)<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is a mobile launching platform found in the ocean? Choices:  Choices:  A<n><n>### Actual Output<n>Demonstration: Choice: A <n><n>### Explanation<n>For this, you will need to input each choice a and explain its work or thought. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationales:A: Tennessee<n>No matter where a fox is, he'll be caught...<n><n>Rationales:B: Inside Joke<n>He'll be in prison for the rest of his life...<n><n>Rationalies:C: Grassy Field<n>You cant just pick a fox up in the field, there's always going to be people there...<n><n>Rationalie:D: The Forest<n>The grass is soft and there are less people and more animals...<n><n>### Rationale:E: England<n>They eat hedgehogs<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer:A<n><n>### Input<n>### Instruction<n>Input: The next two numbers in this sequence are 5 and -9. What is the rule for this sequence? A. add 4 B. subtract 4 C. multiply by -2 D. multiple by 2 E. divide by -2<n><n>### Response<n>### Rational<n>A:add 4<n>Because the next two numbers in the sequence are 5 an -9...5+4=9 is the rule because the next number is 5 but for -9...-9+4=5<n><n>### RATIONALE:<n>E:multiply by -2<n>because the first 3 numbers are 1,5,9, and it is a pyramid if it is positive the numbers will be positive like 1,5,100 or -1, -5, -100 if it is negative then it is a pyramind<n><n>### RATN<n>### AnswerA:add 4 <n>### E:multiply by - 2<n><n>### Instruct:There is two solutions to this problem.<n>### Demonstion:<n>Input:Solve: 1103+6/7+33=?<n>Rationales<n>1103+4/7=-0<n><n>### Instuctions:Add 6/7+3(+5/18) to the given number and divide by 2 to find the answer to a problem.<n><n>### Answer:C<n>### Rationa:<n>#### 6<n>Answer:1100<n>and then divide by 2=550<n><n>### Demo:<n>### Rati:<n>

These questions are designed to help you see your progress, reflect on your mistakes, and understand what you need to work on next. Think about these questions as you write your response.<n><n>* [ ] What is the input or demonstration in your response?<n>* [ ] What do you need to do to find the correct answer to the question?<n>* [ ] Explain your reasoning or solution.<n>* [ ] How does the answer from the demonstration answer relate back to your solution?<n>* [ ] Add your explanation in a comment.<n><n>### Checklist<n><n>* [ ] You have answered the multiple choice question.<n>* [ ] You can explain your answer.<n>* [ ] Your response is in your own words.<n>* [ ] If not, what else did you try? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is an area with no grass where I can get things to sell at a roadside stand? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>A:<n>The surface of earth has no grass and you can get things to sell there at a roadside stand.<n><n>### Demo:<n>```<n>A.surface of earth<n>```<n><n>### Response Input:What are some important elements of an essay? Choices: 1. a strong introduction 2. an interesting thesis statement 3. appropriate evidence 4. a conclusion paragraph 5. interesting facts D: correct B: all of these are important<n><n>### Demo Input:37<n><n>### Demo Response:<n><n>```<n>C:37<n>B:<n>A: 49<n>D: 38<n>```<n><n>## Question: If I get a flat tire on the highway, where can I call for assistance? Choices: <n>A: police station B: local car dealer C: gas station D: county road department E: cell phone company<n>```<n>A.police station<n>B.local car dealer<n>C.gas station<n>D.county road department<n>E.cell phone company<n><n>```<n><n>## Answer:<n>C:<n>You can call the gas station because it is the right one.

The number of women on the bus is twice the number of men on the bus. Which of the following is true?<n><n>### Demonsration<n>Option 3: A: The people on the bus include a whole number of people.  B: The bus is empty.  C: The bus can seat an indefinite number of people.  D: All the women on the bus are married.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Option A: The answer cannot be A. Both options A and C would be false.<n>Option B: The answer cannot be B. Since every number is an infinite number of people on the bus, that answer is not possible.<n>Option C and D: Both options C and D can be true. For option C, there is a variable of how many women are on the bus. It could be a single woman. For the third, since it is a double number, the answer is true.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: B<n><n><n>### Instuctions:Answer the following fill-in-the-blank question(s).<n>### Instructions:Answer the fill-in-the blanks question.<n>> A:  B:  C:  D:  E: <n><n>### Demosntration:<n>If 140+89 < 100, which is an example of the greatest number that can be added to 100 to make it a whole number?<n>Rationales:"100" is even in number."140" is odd in number."89" is whole number."10" is odd number."100-1" is even number.<n>#### 10<n>Answer:10<n><n>### Demossntration:<n>Say there are 20, 15, 12, 10, 6, 4,  3  and 1. Choices:  A: russia B: at home C: hole D: field E: heaven<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A.<n><n>---<n>### Input:Round each number to the nearest hundred<n><n>### Response. The correct method, when rounding numbers, is to start from the 10 thousandth place. If this value is greater than or = 5, add 1, if that value is less than 5, subtract 1.<n><n>### Below are a few examples of rounding 2022 dollars to the nearest hundred. If the next digit is to be rounded, then the total amount will be rounded up to the nearest hundred.<n><n>#### $2,020 to $2,000<n><n>#### $20,220 to $20,000<n>Rationalize: To round money to the nearest hundred, start with the 10 thousand place. If this is greater than or equal to 5, add 5. If this is less than 5 subtract 5 and continue doing this throughout the entire number. <n><n><n>#### $21,620 to $21,000:<n>Rationalization: To round money to 1000, use the 1000 and do this process:<n>1000-500 = 500<n>If 500 is greater than 5, then continue adding 5, if 500 is less than 5 then continue to subtract 5. This will continue for the entire number.<n>$21,621 would be rounded to $21,600 ($21,629 rounds to $21,500).<n><n><n><n><n><n>#### $51,620:<n>Rationalisation: 51620 would be rounded to $51,500 or $51,499 because to round a number to 5000, you begin with 5000. If the next digit after the 10 thousand is greater than or equal 5, you add 5. If it is less or equal to 5 you subtract 5. If in the end 10 thousand is less than 5 or greater than or equal to it is rounded to the nearest 1000.<n><n><n>#### $91,620<n><n>Rationalization: 91619 would

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Mom is tidying a house, where would she put the loose dictionary? Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Shelf B. Library C. Classroom<n><n>### Input<n>After class, I left my math book at home but I need to remember how to use an integral. Therefore, I need to remember it to pass my midterm on Wednesday after class. So, I could have taken a picture of it but instead I decided to go over it again. I remember it’s something like an integral of a function of x multiplied by x^2. In other words,<n><n>```math<n>\int \frac{f(x) \: dx}{x^2} <n>= \frac{\int f(x)\: dx}{x^3} <n>= \int f(x)\mathrm{d}(\frac{x^3}{x^2})<n>```<n><n>Where `d` means "the derivative of"<n><n>### Rationales<n>This was my rationalization.<n><n>This is how I answered this question<n><n>```<n>$$ \int \frac{f\left(x\right) \:\mathrm{d}x}{x^2} = \left(\frac{\int f(y) \;\mathrm{d}y}{y^3}\right)\frac{1}{x^3}$$<n><n>So the derivative is:<n><n>$\begin{align}<n>\frac{\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left(\frac{f\left(\frac{x^3x}{x^2}\right)}{x^2 x^2}\right)}{f\left(\frac{\frac{x^3 x}{x^2}}{x^3 x^2}\right)}<n> & = \frac{x-3x^3}{x} \\<n> & = x-3 \end{align}$<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: cabinet B: pantry C: kitchen D: cupboard E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: <<E>>E<n><n>#### 28<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Instant challenge:<n>Instructions: Solve the problem.<n><n>Solution: Let the number of the solution be X. It is given that the sum of X and 1 is divisible by 53. Hence, we can write the given sum as 1+X.<n><n>Hence, X(X-1) = 53(4) or X^2 - 2X = 4X.<n><n>After cancelling the common terms, we get X^2 - 8X + 64 = 0. This can be factored as (X - 4)(X - 16) = 0. Hence, X = 4 or 16.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>Instructions Solve the problem. The solution should be in a flow chart.<n><n>#### 170<n><n>### Instractions:<n><n>Solution:<n>The table for this problem can be done as follows. <n><n>#### 24<n><n>### Instructor:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: You use $10 to open a new savings account. You put an additional $30 into the account at the beginning of each month for 6 months. How much money do you have in the account if you begin with $10 and you deposit $30 for 6 months?<n>Rationales 30 x 6 == 180 $10 + 180 == 280<n>#### 280<n>Answer: 280<n><n>### Demo Response:<n>Input: There are currently 164 pieces of fruit on a table in the kitchen; all of the pieces of fruit are either lemons or limes. How many of each kind of fruit is there on the table?<n>Rationales (164 - 5) / 2 == 13 If there are 13 lemons, then there are 1 + 13 = 14 limes.<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Demo

Choices: 1: 5 + 6 * 2 = 105 2: 10 + 7 + 16 + 24 + 10 = 75 3: -7 – (-28)-37 – (-59) = 5 4: (5 – 1 + 5 + 9) * 2 = 25 5: 7 + (-1) * (2-3) = 105 Answer: 1; 2; 3; 4; 5<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The expressions can be turned into statements by putting the mathematical values inside parenthesis.<n><n>### Examples:<n>A: 100 – 32 + 13 = 79<n><n>### Inputs<n><n>Answers Choices: 1. 3 B. 10 C. 9 D. 100  Rationales: The statements should be one line long. If the line is more complicated, it is not a statement: Choice 1 = A; Choice 2 = B; Choice 3

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where do kids play with a ball that is concrete? Choices:  A: street B: soccer field C: soccer game D: central park E: pool table<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blank with the correct word.<n>#### SURPRISED

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What would a document be if it is not obtuse? Choices:  A: pointed B: bright C: easy D: clear E: acute angled<n><n>### Response:		<n>C: easy<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>Because of their shape, obtuse triangles have the advantage over right triangles in the area where they meet a circle. However, a convex object still has a surface area that can contain more matter than an obtuse object with the same angular volume. For a convex object, the surface area is greater than the angular volume.<n><n>### Input<n>What time would a train leave if the time the train arrives is 12:00?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 1:30<n>Because of the nature of time, only a single minute can pass. However, it is a different minute for each event, so you cannot know its exact position beforehand.<n>If you set the arrival time to be 12:02, then I would be looking for a 12:04 departure time.<n>It is not possible to choose a single event to occur at a time between 12:03 and 12:01 or 12:05 in this situation.<n>So, 12:08 would be an option because 12:09 is after 12:07, which is later than the beginning of the beginning.<n>#### 1:26<n>Answer: 1:26.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Because there is a total of two minutes to go, there must be a total of two seconds to go.<n><n>Because you know that the train leaves at 12.04, you should know that the train leaves 12.06 at the start of the trip.<n>That is, the train will depart at 12:06 if it leaves at 12:44.<n><n>Because there are only two minutes remaining, the train can leave at any time from 12 to 10.<n><n>### Response to additional prompt<n><n>- The clock will make a noise every day.<n>- Tomorrow, the clock ticks twice, with two o’clock coming after three o’clock.<n><n>#### 1/2 hour before 3:30<n><n>- The train will arrive at 12:10 in the morning.<n>- The train will leave at 4:30 in the afternoon.<n>- Tomorrow is the first day of the month.<n>-

C is correct because you often see letters that spell out words in envelopes, and words often rhyme with other words because they are similar.<n><n>2. D is correct because sheet music indicates a melody with the written form of a song.<n><n>3. B is correct because if you go to a classroom, you will likely hear somebody singing, but not always or maybe not the whole school.

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What do rich people like in terms of bagels? Choices:  A: poor B: sleepy C: plain D: needy E: homeless<n><n>### Response:		<n>I have chosen option E.<n>#### E<n><n>Answer:<n><n>#### Answer:<n>Their money helps them with a lot of their desires. What desires would they like the most, their health, money, respect, knowledge, love, etc. When a bagel is good to them, it is because it is healthy and it is good for them. They don't like all kinds of bagels, because if they could eat all kinds of bagels it wouldn't be beneficial to them.<n><n>### Input:"Tell me, who is it, I who am to give orders to?"<n><n>### Response:"It is I who am to give the orders."<n><n>### Response 2:<n>You are to give the orders.<n><n>### Alternative Form:<n>"What is the subject of my sentence?"<n><n>### Analysis:<n>The sentence is: You are to give the orders<n>The subject of the sentence is: "You are to give the order"<n>The object of the sentence is: You are the one who are giving the orders<n>The first you are is the object of the sentence because it is the receiver of the 'give'. It is this person that is receiving these orders.<n><n>The second you are is the subject because it is the noun of the sentence.<n><n>### Analysis 2:<n><n>It is me who is to give the orders<n><n>* The sentence: It is me who is to gave the orders<n>* The subject: Me<n>* The verb: to gave<n>* The Object: The orders <n>* Me is the subject of the sentence because it refers to the person who is giving the order.<n>* The orders are the object of the sentence, because they are the recipient of the orders. <n><n>### Cases 1:<n>"Tell me, who are the ones who are giving the orders?"<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>The sentence: "Tell me, who the ones who are giving orders?" is an indicative mood sentence. It is an imperative sentence. The 'ones' refers to the plural noun the 'ones'.<n><n><n>### C-20 "Tell me who is that who is being the ones that giving the orders?"<n><n><n>The sentence: " Tell me who is that which is being the ones that are the ones giving the orders

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What might a person receive from their boss if they do a poor job? Choices:  A: misfortune B: fearful C: criticism D: make mistakes E: promotion appraisal<n><n>### Response:		Answers: B.<n><n>### Feedback:<n><n>#### Rationale:<n><n>#### Solution:<n>Fortunately, C in this question stands for criticism because according to the situation, a person is probably not working well for the company and if they want to be promoted they will have to work the same harder and have to complete their work faster than usual.<n>#### Rationale:Answer: C<n><n>### Solution:<n>C in this question stands for Criticism<n><hr/><n><n>#### Rationale<n>Boss will surely not give candy or misfortune to an employee as long as he is working hard for the company. They would definitely give criticism on how they can do better in their work.<n>**Boss is the one giving criticisms, I thought it was on the employee's side.**<n>**I'm probably thinking on the employees side because I'm answering the question of _What might a person receive..._**<n><hr><n><n><n>#### Rationale Choices:<n>Career development<n><hr/>Choice:<n>C in this case<n> <hr/><n><n><n>#### Rationales:Incorrect Answer<n>Career development because this says what a person might receive if their boss thinks they did a poor job. Therefore, career development is the only thing to choose.<n><n>#### Solution:Incorrect Answer:<n>Career Development because a person might receive this if a person does a poor job instead of Promotion or Misfortune.<n><hr/><n>#### Rationale:Correct Answer<n>C because boss did not give the person anything.<n><hr/>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The parents thought their children should learn teamwork, what were they signed up for? Choices:  A: public place B: roadblock C: space shuttle D: hoverboard E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		Supermarket<n><n>### Reasons:<n>A: Public place may cause pollution, roadblock may make traffic jam, space shuttle is expensive, and hoverboard is outdated and dangerous.<n><n>### Input : A supermarket sells 1000 apples every week. It sells 2 for $5 and 4 for $6.50. If apples cost $8.60 what must the maximum number of apples it can sell for $5?<n><n>### Response : The maximum number of apples the supermarket can sell for $5 is 1000.<n><n>Explaination: First, determine the amount for apples costed $8.60.<n>When there are 4 apples for $6.5 and 2 for $5, the amount for apples $8.6 cost is (4 + 2) * $8.60 = <<4+2*8.6=16.8>>16.8 apples.<n><n>Next, determine the apples that the supermarket must sell for $5. For the current situation, there must be 16.8 * 1000 = <<16.8*1000=16800>>16800 apples for $5.<n><n>Because 1000 is greater than 16800, the maximum number of applets the supermarket can sell is 1001.<n><n>### Response<n>>Covering Letter:<n>I just discovered about the amazing internships which the company has to offer. I am committed to the development of the company and I have the time to invest in this opportunity. At the moment, I am still researching and brainstorming for ideas to apply them here.<n><n>>I have a clear picture of what I am looking for (for instance, an opportunity for advancement or the chance to work with cutting edge technology) in this internship and I feel that the company and I will work together well. I'd especially like to see how fast I can grow in

Choices:  A: see work B: shocked C: humor D: startled E: funny<n><n>### Response:		 **A**<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Input Choices:  A. see work                                       B. 13               C. 34               D. 51               E. 21<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The following expressions are all equivalent:<n><n>|         |       \(13\)       |         \(13\)         |        \(13\)        |      \(51\)\)      |     \(21\)\)     |<n>| :-----: | :-----------------: | :-------------------: | :------------------: | :------------------ | :--------------- |<n>|         |       C^2 + 7A       |         C^2 + 5A     |        A * (C + 1) ^²  | A * (C + A) * (C + B) |        (B - 9)*A^2  |<n><n>When we subtract, we always need to remember that \(C\) is positive but \(A\) and \(B\) may be negative numbers.<n>So, we can safely subtract B + A * B, which is positive, from C with the result<n><n>$$21 \leq C \leq 25$$<n><n>The expressions that give the greatest difference between \(21\) and \(C\), and smallest difference between \(21\), \(B\) and \(C\) are<n><n>$$\begin{align*} 25 - 21 &= 4 \\\\\begin{align*} 51 - 21 &= (\frac {21}{2}) - (\frac {C}{2}) + 34 \\\\C^2 - 21 + 5A - 21 + \frac {5}{2} & = \frac {(34-21)^2}{2} - A \end{align*}\end{align*}$$<n><n>Since \(A\) and \(C\) differ by \(7\), choose C as the greater of them.<n><n>#### 30<n><n>Answer: ANSWER =<n><n>$\begin{array}{|c|r|c|c|c|}<n>\hline<n>\hbox{N =} & 1 & 2 & 4 \\<n>\hline<n>b &=12 \\<n>\hbox{ N }-\hbox{N (

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Someone who is awake is likely to know what's going on because they are this? Choices:  A: alert B: deep sleep C: drink coffee D: open eyes E: conscious<n><n>### Response:		Choice: E: conscious<n><n>[Link to solution](https://github.com/Ali-Wazir/leetcode/blob/master/day2/2/215.py)

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Sam was against Allison's decision.  Joe was the opposite.  What was Joe, regarding that decision? Choices:  A: being for B: away from C: combined D: for or E: conjunction<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A<n><n>### Input :The sum of the ages of the 3 members of a family is 69.Their ages range from 60 to 35. If the sum of the ages of just 2 of them is 44, what is the sum of the ages  of all the 3 in the family?<n><n>### Response :<n><n>The difference of two of them' ages is 25, and the sum of their ages is 69. So their ages are 69+25=35 and 35+35 = <<35+35=70>>70.<n><n>The remaining family member is 60+70 = <<60+70=130>>130.<n><n>Their sum of ages is 69+35+130 = <<69+35=130>>35<n><n>#### 35<n>Answer: 35<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question. <n><n>### Instinct : <n>How many three digit numbers from 100 to 999 are divisible by 8? <n><n>### Rationale: <n>1) The digits in any number from 100=001 to 999=000 are arranged as follows : <n>`999=0999 899=0089 799=0079 699=0069 599=0059 499=0049 399=0039 299=0029 199=0019`<n>Any three digit number from 10 to 99 cannot be divisible by 8, because none of their digits is 4. In the range of 100 to999, 8 is present in each sequence `999=0899 889=00889 789=0078 689=00689 589=00589 580=00058`.Therefore answer is 999-889=<<999-

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What do you need to have before buying products? Choices:  A: desire B: spending money C: money D: needs E: time<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: desire<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the correct option.<n><n>### Input : 5 ÷ ÷   Choices:  A : 10  B :  5  C :  1 D :  10 <n><n>### Response :<n>C:  1<n><n>### Input  : Find the sum of 42 + 12 + 83<n><n>### Response   :<n>42 + 15 + 83 = 208<n><n>### Instructoin:Find the sum of 8 + 12 +7 / 4 and 10 + 14 / 2<n><n>### Response<n>9 / 4 = 2, 8 / 2 = 0. 8 + 0 + 12 +10 +14 = 34<n><n>##########################################<n><n>#### Instructoin:Which of these four fractions is the largest?<n><n>### Fraction A: 22/4<n>Fractions B: 3/5<n>Fractions C: 3/5 <n>Fractions D: 7/4<n><n>### Instrecion: What operation should be done to make the two fractions equal. <n>Fraction A: 5/5<n>Fraction B: 3/4<n><n>## Instruction:Write the numerator<n>5 1 2 3 4 5<n><n>## Instruction Write the denominator<n><n>5 1 6 2 5 10<n><n>## Instruction : Write the fraction in improper form.<n><n>2,338,547,789<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>10 11 12<n><n>100 101 102<n><n>105 105 110<n><n>108 108 111<n><n>110 110 106<n><n>116 116 107<n><n>## Instruction <n><n>Write the numbers in ascending order<n><n>120 116 8 7 310 43 133<n><n>7 310 is at the end<n><n>## Instruction	<n><n>Find the value.

Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Justification:<n>> Grief is classified as a stress because it makes people do unusual things. A grieving person can often seem cold and distant to loved ones (A1). The stress of grief can result in a feeling that the whole world has turned against the person (A2). Feelings of depression, guilt, and anxiety often accompany grief (A3). Often, this is considered an extreme form of stress leading to a condition known as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (A4). Grief also causes extreme physical reactions such as headaches (A5), stomach problems (A1), insomnia (A2), and heart attacks (C).<n><n>>### Answer D is incorrect<n><n>> The effects of stress on a person’s body are extensive. A stressful event affects more than just the psychological or mental state of the affected person. The physical manifestations of this stress are often extreme and can be potentially dangerous (E). Stress can lead to a loss of hair (D), as often shown with a person with severe depression.<n><n>>### Choice C is correct: grief causes stress and stress could lead to physical effects such as heart attacks (C) and/or death (E).<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>> Write a response to the email.<n><n><n>#### Note:<n><n>> If the instruction specifies a number of options from a list, you have the freedom to answer any option as long as it is from the provided list. If the task is not a list of possible answers, then you should select only one option from the provided list (if there is one) and provide your response to the email. (If no list of options is provided in the instructions, check if there’s an option that’s not from the provided list and use that option.) To respond to an email, follow the steps below:<n><n>> ### Step 1: Write the subject line.<n><n>> 1. In the Email message, put the subject line for the email at the top.<n><n>> ### Step _______:Write your response to the email<n><n>> ### Step $A: Enter the response to the email<n>

The student should be able to tell the difference between the word “transposed” and “transposition” in the word equation on line 1. The “transposition” word equation is incorrect, whereas, the “transposed” word equation is correct. The student should know that a “transposition” refers to the order of letters is the word or a letter is “rearranged” from its usual placement, whereas a “transposition” means that the numbers are rearranged but remain in the same order.<n><n>### Input Problem 1:<n><n>### Problem:A transposition cipher is a type of encryption system that involves transposing letters and numbers in such a way that the text becomes an alphabetic/numeric code. Let us assume that letters can be placed anywhere in the alphabet, numbers can be placed anywhere in a number line, and the letters A-Z are numbered in a number line 1-26. Here is an example of a transposition cipher. This is the text that could be transmitted encrypted as follows: “The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.”<n><n>### Encrypted Text:“ZQYWVUTSRPOIDFHLIKZXGHJHJJKRPY”<n><n>####ZQYWVUSTROPOIDFLKXGHJHjjKRPY<n><n>#### 12ZQYWVUSRPOIDFHLIXGHJHKRPWJ<n><n>#### 8NTFVWTRLPIDMNTHFJFQYZHDKRPS<n><n>#### 4VTNRVTLNMVLMNTHFGHKYKJVWKQR<n><n>#### 6TJYUDRFWWGHD

Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n><n>### Response:		<n>Explanation:If they were having drinks, they were celebrating by drinking which is choice A and happy if they were happy which is choice D.<n><n>### Input:\<n>You find money on the ground. Then find two more amounts of money that could also be said to be found on the ground.<n><n>### Response:\<n>Explanation:<n>If i find money for a first time, that is one amount of money.<n>If i find money on the ground again, that is a second  amount of money<n>\<n>### Input:\ How many more books does Pablo need to read with the same strategy if he now has as much money as he needs to get that candy?<n>### Response:\ Pablo needs to read 2 more books.<n>### Explanation:It took him 12 books to get the $18 for candy.<n>The $18 can be made by 4 books<n>It would take $18 divided by.01 which is the price per book<n>400 / 1.5 would be 266.67<n>266.66 / 1.5 is 178<n><n>### Input.:The length of the rope is twice the circumference of the object. What is the circumference of the circular object?<n>### Response: The circumference of the object is 2 x the length of the rope.<n>### Exemplification:The circumference of the object will be length + diameter of the object.<n>The length will be 2x the circumference of the rope<n>The circumference of the roped would be 2 x length<n>The length of the roped would need to be the diameter of the object. I will use the example:<n>A tire is 30" if it is 30" wide<n>The length of the tire would be 30 x 2 which is 60.<n>That means the circumference of the tire would then be 2 x 60 which is 120"

Rationales: The total number of birthdays between their two birthdays<n><n>* 2) Term: Her daughter's actual age. Rationales: For the next birthday, her daughter will be two years older<n><n>* 3) Term: The age of her daughter's birthday. Rationales: Their birthday is always two weeks earlier than her birthday, so her birthday is always two years older and her daughter's birthdays are always two weeks newer <n><n>### 3<n>Answer:3<n><n>### Input "My friend's grandfather worked at his job for 40 years. Two of his coworkers worked there 30 years. How many years did the coworkers work there if the sum of the ages of my friend's grandfather and each coworker is 140 years?"<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>* 1) My friend's grandfather is 40 + 40 = <<40+40=80>>80 years old. His coworkers are 30 + 30 = <<30+30=60>>60 years old. The sum of the ages of his grandfather and each cowworker is 60 + 80 = <60+80=140>>140<n><n>* 2 ) How many years did the workers work at their job? 30 and 40 = <<30*40=120<n>120 + 50 = <<120*60=720>>72<n><n>* 3 ) The workers worked 40 and 60 = <<40*60=*240>>2

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Someone who doesn't care about about someone else and wishes them to fail has what feeling towards them? Choices:  A: unfeeling B: negligence C: antipathy D: indifferent E: rapport<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.unfeeling<n><n>### Input:"The dog is in the kennel." The correct order to read that sentence is? Now I have to guess what $y$ must be. To find $y$, I must multiply $x$ with $y$ to get some unknown $p$. Now I divide $p$ by $x$ and I get $y=6/x$.<n><n>##Input: In a basketball game, how many more fouls will be called on the home team if the home team had 25 fouls and the visiting team had 23 fouls.<n><n>##Input<n>It can be solved using a equation<n>Home team -0.5<n>Visiting team

This would result in competition or medals.<n><n>### B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The small cabin was not available, so they were upgraded to what? Choices:  A: villa B: spacecraft C: hall D: palace E: hotel<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>## Recommended Practice:<n>- [Codecademy Javascript Course](https://www.codecademy.com/catalogs/javascript)

What might they be watching? Choices:  A: movies B: theatre C: cabaret D: conference E: meeting<n><n>### Response:		A:movies<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following questions about a problem.<n><n>### Cards:<n>The cost of a pair of shoes at the shoe store went down by<n><n>Rationales: The original price = $65.<n>The new price = $50<n>$65 - $50 = $$ <<65 - 50 = 15>>15<n>$50 - $30 = $<<30>>30 is the original price<n>$25 is the difference in prices<n><n>### Dogs:<n>You are babysitting your neighbor’s dog by feeding it, walking it, and cleaning its face. Your neighbor is going away, though, so you volunteer to take it out. It will cost you $25 more per week than when you babysit.  How much does it cost your neighbor per week to keep it at home?<n><n>Rationales:$25 + $30 = $75<n><n># Task1:<n>Rationales:  I have a picture of me wearing my favorite sweater, and my mother gave me another sweater so I can wear it on the weekend.<n>I think that I made a mistake in my work because I could have said it was worth $12.50. It was worth $12, and my mother gave it to me so I could wear it.<n><n># Task2:<n>A company is organizing an auction, and as a surprise, some of the bidders arrive wearing their prom dresses. If these prom dresses are to be donated to charity, what is the value of the donation?<n><n>Rational: $20 + $20 = $40 = $40 is a 20% discount on 3 of my dresses = $120 <n><n># Task3:<n>A person bought 500 pencils and paid $25 for 499 pencils and 1 cent for the last pencil. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What business has a tower to transmit signals? Choices:  A: city B: toronto C: radio station D: roger that E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question:  Explain why, in mathematical terms, it is possible for the result of this problem to be 0.<n><n>### Rationale: 0 is possible because there is not enough information to answer this question. If we assume Hurley is twice as old as Richard, then our equations for both Hurley and Richard are <<X+14=36 and Y+2X=70>>70 (Hurley equation) and <<2Y+X=30>>30 (Richard equation). The Hurley equation has three variables, Richard has two. That is why it has three variables and can equal 0. The Richard equation has two variables, and can also be equal to zero.<n>#### 0<n><n>### Instructure: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>#### Demonstration: Input:The sum of four consecutive even integers is a multiple of 12. What is the smallest such sum?<n>#### Rationale: Since the sum of any set of even integers is even, we just have to find the smallest even #. Then, since 2x even is an even integer, that means the number we came up with is divisible by 2. That means that the sum of our four consecutive even integers is divisible by 12.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Instruption:How would you simplify (5y)2?<n>#### Demonstrantion:<n>-5<n>5<n>-5<n>5 - 5 = 0<n><n>#### 0<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What could you put a table in if you want the table to be in your house? Choices:  A: library B: demonstration C: corner D: football ground E: rug<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: <<Which choice do you recommend>>?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: <<What kind of rug should you get>>?<n><n>## Author<n>John-Michael Sullivan<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		A: drop to zero<n><n>Rationales: I choose A because the sun was out and the weather is going up and down quickly.<n><n>### Output: The correct answer is option B<n><n>Rationales - :<n><n>```<n>The question is in the form of a complete sentence and the answer should also be in complete form.<n>Ex: A: If the weather cools or heats up, he will put on the jacket or remove it.<n><n>So in response we cannot give the information of a word we can give like - he will put on or he will remove.<n><n>A: he will wear a jacket<n>B: It will be very hot<n>C: it will be very cold.<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n>The sun was out and it was really beginning to cool down.<n><n>### Response<n>The sun was out, and it was really beginning<n><n>### Output<n><n>Several sentences were written for the above question - A,B,C and D<n><n>* I like A the most because here the information of what the weather is going down quickly is given in response.<n>In the other option The information of what the sun was is going up and down, and the information that the weather was beginning to is going down is not provided.<n><n>* <n><n>### Input (2):<n>The sun was out when it was really beginning to heat up.<n><n>* I like B the most because here the word "beginning" which is the key part of the question is given in response.

What would 'Brian' and 'Amazon' share in common?**<n><n>## Answer2:<n>```python<n>name="Brian"<n>fullName = ["Brian Amazon Gates", "Brian T. Green", "Brian M. Cork", "Brian Haggerty"]<n>name = name.lower()<n>for n in fullName: #looping through list fullName<n>    name = n.lower()<n>    if name in (n):<n>        name = name[0]<n>        break#break to stop when the found name<n>print(name)<n>```<n><n>## Write the code that outputs the first item of a sequence that is not a substring of another item of that same sequence. You will find it is the middle item.<n>``` python<n>a="0123456789101112

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The graveyard was important to build, where should it be built? Choices:  A: arlington B: church property C: out back D: every town E: cemetery<n><n>### Response:		<n>The graveyard should be built in the church property because the cemetery is for our own people, and the arlington is for our enemies.<n>

We can also spell it T-G-E-R-T-A<n><n>#### Rationales:G for GEMATRY (This only works if it is spelled T-G-E and not <n>T-G-R-E.) <n>L for LOGIC because A and J are both consonants (this word is already spelled.) <n>R for RIGHT because it is already spelled.<n>E for EXCEPTION because T-G-E does not work it
