Choices:  A: pocket B: office supply store C: friend's house D: desk drawer E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		<n>You’d carry a pen in your pocket.<n><n>#### Answer A<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: The carpet factory makes carpets from wool by weaving yarn onto a loom. On Monday, the manufacturer unloaded 112,000 pounds of wool, and used 10% of it to make carpets. How much of the wool was not used to make carpets?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The factory uses 10% to make carpets, so 100% - 10% = <<100-10%=90%>>90% of the 112, 000 pounds is not used to make carpet.<n><n>```<n>${{112000*90}/100}=$111,200<n>```<n><n>${12,005} grams<n><n>#### 12,004<n>Answer: $12, 054 grams<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>* 1112200 / 100 = <<11122/100>>122 pounds<n>* 122/16 = <<122/14>>122/1.4<n>* 400/14 = <<400/1.4>>28.5 grams<n>* 414/14 = <<1228.5>>28.45 grams<n><n>## Task<n><n>Input: The city of Salem has a water tower that holds roughly 5 million gallons, but most people need water from home pipes. In the water park, one faucet uses 25 gallons per minute. Which statement about those facts is NOT true?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Water towers usually hold a lot of water which is then distributed by pipes. Thus 5 million gallons = <<5 million gallons=7.8 x 10^6>>78<n><n>Water parks have faucets that can quickly fill a small pool. However, that is not nearly as much water as a water tower. Therefore 78L / 25 = <<78/25=3.15>>3

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:A shark swam in the background aquarium as the card players sat emotionless, what were they playing? Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Fundamental:<n><n>Letter, Letter, Shape<n>The three card players were playing cards.<n><n>### Input(Rationales):<n>The shark was swimming in the background aquarium, so the game was underwater. The game was played with cards, so it was a card game. It was played with emotions. The word "emotionless" is important here. The players were being calm and composed during gameplay, which was the best way they could be for the game. They did not need a card shark. Therefore, the players were not playing poker. The card players did play court, so it was an indoor game. Therefore, the game was not played in shallow waters. Therefore, the players went to sea world.<n><n>### Fundamental:<n><n>You don't know the person who answered your question.  Write a response.<n><n>### You don't know the instructor who is giving you some directions about their homework.  Write a response to help them.<n>#### Your Response:<n><n>I don't know the instructions, but I can tell the person what needs to be done: They need to follow the instructions.<n><n>### The instructions for a new computer program are unclear. Choose an option that will give you clarity.<n><n>#### Clarity:<n>When an answer is unclear it is often a good idea to call upon others to help clarify the situation.  Try using the name of the people you are talking to when asking for help.<n>#### Example:<n>Your brother says, "I ran out of cat food."  Your response should be:<n><n>#### A:   When did you run out of cat food?<n><n>#### B:   How many times do you run out of catfood?<n><n>#### C:   Is that all there is to eat around here?<n><n>#### Answer:<n>Which option could you ask your brother to get more clarity so your brother can help you?<n><n>#### Your Response: You have some options. These options are in the answer choices.<n><n>#### A:  When did you run out? If you ask him to tell you when he ran out of cat food, you will get more clarity about running out.  That way he might remember things that he forgot or knew better, which would help you help your brother.<n><n>#### C: Is that all there is

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Lilly owns the only kosher deli in the area.  She isn't in a heavily populated area.  Where might she live? Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input<n>Richard's uncle is an artist. He paints landscapes, and he always paints scenery that is based in reality.  How would this artist paint the Grand Canyon?  Choices:  A. painting of the Grand Canyon<n>B. painting of the Grand Teton<n>C. painting of the Rocky Mountains<n>D. painting of the Sierra Nevada mountains  E. painting of a mountain<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input (Demonstration)<n>Sally is taking a plane to Washington, D.C. from New York. When she gets to Washington, D. C., she is planning on taking a train to Philadelphia. Sally is traveling by herself. Does the following statement describe her route of travel?  Choices: A. Sally will take a plane from New York to Washington, D.  C. and then take a train to Philadelphia<n>B. Sally will take the plane from New York to Philadelphia and take a train from Philadelphia to Washington, D.   C.<n>C. Sally will travel from New York to Philadelphia, and then she will take a train from Philadelphia back to Washington, D.<n>C. S<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### InputBradley is 2/5 of Shel’s age.  Shel is 43 years old.  Can you write a division problem to find Bradley's age?<n>### Rational<n>When Bradley is 2/3 = <<2/3=67>>67 of Shel's age,<n>Bradley will be 67 / (2/3) of 67 = <<67/(2/3)= 92>>92 years old.<n>Bradley will need to be 43+92 = <<43+92=135>>135 years old to be 2/5 = <<2/5=60>>60 of Shel's<n>4/5 = <<4/5=80>>80, to get the age ratio correct.<n><n>### Answer:41<n>

What is the missing number, X?<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>Each of the 5 squares shows 1/2 of the square. But, for 33%, you have to multiply that by 2.<n><n>####33% \$\overset{5-squares}{2-squares per segment}\$ \$\overset{2-squares per square}{2-squares}\$ \$\overlap{10-squares}\$ <n><n>__ **X $\%$ = $50\%$__<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Input <n><n>**1. Sara will be 33 in 13 years and Robert is 9 years older than Sara. What is Robert’s age?<n>### Rationales: The difference in ages = 4 and Robert is <9-<4=5>5 times older than Sara. As she is older by <x>, so Robert is older by 5-x= <<5-x=4>>4<n>=> Robert is 45 years old. She will be 33 years from today and the 33+20 (as Sara will be 20 years older than <y> at 60) years from now.<n>=> Robert's age will be 63.<n><n>### Inputs: The sum of two numbers equals -13. The sum of the first and second number is 4. What are the two numbers?<n>### Output: The sum of two integers a and b is -13 and the sum of a+b is 4.<n>### Rationals: The sum of the first<a> and second<b> number is 4.<n>Since sum of <a> and sum of <b> is 4, their difference should be<k>.<n>=> <a-b=(a+b)-2a=2a-b>=k<n>=> The sum of <a> is -13 and sum of <b>= +7<n>=>The sum of <a> should be 13, and b should be -7.<n><n>### Summary<n>Input: If I wanted to thank someone who told me I did a good job, what should I say? Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Answer:C<n><n>### Rationales: A:run programs-> Programs - programs in a computer that can be run for a variety of applications. Programs are also called software. Examples of some kinds of computer programs include word processors, games, spreadsheet apps, and digital media players. Games: Games are programs that instruct a computer to perform certain tasks.<n>B:play games-> Play - in game terminology, play refers to the act of competing against another character in a video game. Examples of games that require character play include strategy games, such as Risk or Civilization, first-person shooters, and role-playing games.<n>C:control model -> Modelling – A form of computer programming that uses structured or object oriented methods of programming.<n><n>### Explanation:(1).  His day at the office was nearly complete, he wanted to shut his system by using it.<n><n>### Answer not supported by a program:E: not present<n><n>Example: When you're on the desktop of your computer, you see icons that represent the applications you've installed. You'll find the Windows taskbar (at the bottom of your screen). You can go to start to open a program, or shut down the entire computer.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where should an excavation never take place? Choices:  A: construction site B: cemetary C: building D: city E: archeological site<n><n>### Response:		The dig site should never taken place in a cemetary because they respect the dead.<n><n>### Input<n>Choose the right code block to complete the method chain. Where might he be? Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>The only choice that is specific enough for the question is Answer C (garden).  Muddy shoes could be outside, but unless Sam has a garden, he is most likely not there.  Because there is not much else to choose from, Answer C is probably the correct answer.<n><n>### Input (Multiple Choice):Another choice would be to say, ‘Himself,’ which is a statement that would be most appropriate when writing a text message to your mom about where you are. Choices: A: at school B: home C: in the garden D: at work E: myself (Himself)<n><n>### Response (Multiple Choice)<n><n>Another choice would be Choice C (in the garden).  This choice is specific enough and answers the question correctly.<n><n>### Explain:The word is “himself.”  If you are using “himself” to refer to a second person, the pronoun would end “-self.”  However, you wouldn't put “-self” on the end of the pronoun if you were using it to refer to the first person or yourself.<n><n>Answer: <n>## Explain:<n>In the instruction, the first part of the question asks a yes/no question.  “Where might he be?” is a yes/no question that implies that he is most likely not where he is meant to be.  After, the last paragraph restates the first question, but in a much simpler way.  By restating the question in simpler terms, it indicates that the correct answer is a statement, “Answer C (garden).”<n><n>## Question:What kind of sentence might be appropriate to text to a friend about your whereabouts?<n><n>## Answer:<n>A full sentence is most appropriate for the question.  A full sentence allows the reader to know who the subject is, what kind of action they are taking, and to whom the action is happening.  Full sentences are the best option for texting.<n><n>## Instruction:Sam and Julio’s school, a boarding school in California, had a special activity after chapel. Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		Choice: A<n><n>### Input & Demonstration: The sum of the factors of 2^3^8^ + 5 + 7 + 10 + 13 = 144 Because 2^3^ and 5 are the factors of 2 and 8, they do not need to be multiplied out. For example 8 (2^3^) = 2^6 10 (5) = 50 7 (10) = 70 20 (4) = 80 Thus, the factors of the given number are 1, 2, 4, 8, 10, 14, 16, 32, 36, 72, 80, 96.<n><n>### Response & Rationale: Let's look at how big this number is and the way it's structured. We can break it down for easier understanding.<n><n>$\begin{array}{rr}<n>144 &= [2^{3} + 5 + 6 \cdot 7 + 13]<n>\\<n>&= [1 + (3 \cdot 4)] + [5 \cdot 6 \cdot 2^3] + [7 \cdot 13]<n>\end{array}$<br><n>Here's where things get a little interesting. Let's factor (5 \cdot 6) = 30, then since 30 = (2 \cdot 5) or [2^{2} \cdot 5] we can write the sum as $[2^3 + (6 \cdot 2) + 5 +2 \cdot 5]. \ \ \checkmark$<n><n>We are left with:<br>$144 = [1 + 6 + 5 + 2 \cdot 5] = [7 + 2 \cdot (30)] = [2^3 + [6 \cdot 10] + [5 \cdot (3 \cdot 2)]]$ <br><n>... and we're done.<n><n>__Note:__ The original method works too, but it requires a lot more computation.<br>$148 = [2^{3} \cdot 4 \cdot 9 + 5 + 13] = [2^{3}] +

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Why would a person be approached by a lot of people? Choices:  A: care about B: compliments C: know all D: popularity E: understand themselves<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Rationales: Care about is the answer. We don't compliment anybody, people don't know all, and nobody is popular except themselves. They are the only one who care abou something<n><n>### Source: https://hackerrank.com/en-US/challenges/popularity-3<n><n>### Input<n>The following code contains statements that run while the value of v (v is used as variable) is less than 10. Each time through the loop v has been increased by 1. Write one statement to print the value of v after the loop has ended.<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 9<n>Answer: 9<n><n>### Challenge: The following code contains statements that read input from the keyboard until 10 lines have been read. Write five statements that read input from standard input.<n><n>### #<n>#  1  2  3  4  5<n># 6  7  8  9  10<n><n>### Response - Input:<n>cat(1,'line 1','line 2','line 3','line 4','line 5','line 6','line 7','line 8','line 9','line 10')<n><n>### Source - https://hackerrank<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a program that prints out the number of odd integers, even integers, and prime numbers that are less than or equal to 100.<n>### Source: <n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### #include<n>std::cout << "Odd numbers";<n><n>std::cout << "\n" << "Even numbers";<n><n>std ::cout << "\n"<< "Primes";<n><n>### function main<n>int prime = 0,odd = 0,even = 0;<n><n>for (int i = 1; i <= 100; i++)<n>{<n><n>   if (i % 2 == 0)<n><n>   even++;<n><n>   for (int j = 2; j < i; j++)<n><n>   if ( i % j == 0)<n> {   even!= 0;<n><n>}<n>if (i % 2!=0)<n>    odd++ ;<n>   else {<n>      even ++

Write about 5 sentences that describe why you chose which answer is best for the question.<n><n>## Question 3<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Input: You are on a beach. You notice 3 birds: blue, green, and reddish brown. The blue bird is 4 times as likely to say "Hello!" as the green bird, and twice as likely to say "hello" as the reddish bird. What is the probability that one of them says "hello," and that it is the green bird?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: I saw two birds, both birds say "Hello!"<n>Rationales: Out of the total 2 birds, there's one bird says "Hello!" and the rest says "Hi."<n>Out of the two, one bird says "Hello" and one says "Hi."<n>I had the green bird says "Hello" with a probability of 4/7 and the reddish bird says "Hello" to have a probability of 8/7<n>I had the green says "Hello" with probability 4/5 and the reddish says "Hello" with 2/5<n>The combined probability for the case when the probability for the green bird is 4/5 and that of reddish is 2/5 is 6/5<n>The total two birds say "Hello" is 6/5 x 1<n>The total two birds saying "Hello" is 1<n>### Question 3:<n>Input: What is the length of a rectangle whose width is 2.8 ft and its height is 3.6 ft.<n><n>Input: How much does 2 lb of sand weigh? <n>Answer: 2 lb * 2.2 lb = 4.4 lb or 4 lb and 4.4 lb<n><n>### Input a statement that describes a situation:<n>- You have to ride a plane for 2.5 hours to get from Miami to New York City<n>- When riding a plane, each passenger pays $14,000<n>- The flight schedule has 4 seats and passengers can only pay by cash, debit card, or PayPal<n>- Ticketing begins at 8:00 a.m. and ends at 8:30 a.m.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What planet is the atlantic ocean part of? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		The instruction word “eternal” is used to describe the parties held every day of the year. This can also be true of the word "frequent” since it also describes things that happen multiple times in a row. "Everyday” is synonymous with “frequent." Although this is an everyday event, it is never frequent. "Frequent" is rarely used in this sense.<n>The word most appropriate to complete this sentence is: _________<n>#### <n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input The following is a list of terms used to describe different modes of travel. Which is not an appropriate travel mode for a short distance?<n><n>### Choices:<n>  A: plane<n>  B: trolley<n>  C: buss<n>  D: train<n><n>### Response Train is an appropriate travel term for short distances. Although all travel terms are used for everyday activities, this term is used for long-distance trips.<n><n>### The word most appropriate to complete the sentence is __________.<n>####<n>Answer: D

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What will happen to your knowledge with more learning? Choices:  A: headaches B: bigger brain C: education D: growth E: knowing more<n><n>### Response:		You're so danged smart<n>#### F<n>Answer: F<n><n>### Input:(216/12) mod 7<n><n>### Response:(216/32) mod 7/12<n>#### 60<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:"The price of this book is $20.00." He plans to buy 128 books and save the money for the candy. He checks out books that are 128 pages each. After reading his books he went to the store, bought $128 worth of candy. How many books does Pablo read?<n>Rationale: If he reads books of 128 pages, then he read 128 books. Now he needs money. He earned $1.5 per by reading, which makes $18. He also studies and practices guitar for a total of 20 hours per week. For vacation, Sam and his family went to the library for two and a half hours, and also he read The Hobbit for an hour while his mother ironed clothes. Write an expression using addition and subtraction to find the total number of pages Sam read during the week.<n>Rationale: While staying in the vacation for 2 hours 30 minutes, he read 1/3 of a page because he needed to read 20/3=<<20/3=6.7>>6.7 page per vacation hours.<n><n>Hourly reading rate = 6.7 pages/per hour.<n><n>Total number of pages = (The number of hours for reading with out of total hours)*The reading rate in number of pages per hour<n><n>Total number of hours * Total Hours / Total Hours + 2.5* 1/3 = 61 * 106.66/109 + 2.5 * 6.5666 = 12991 pages * (1.0666 + 0.6566) = 12946 pages.<n><n>#### 12947<n>Answer: 13000<n><n>Input: The robot shockingly began to learn

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:There is a lot of sugar in what food that fits in your hand? Choices:  A: cupboard B: chocolate C: coffee D: candy bar E: soda pop<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demostration:Because the smallest measure for sugar is the cupboard you need to choose the cupboard which is the smallest and that belongs in your hand<n><n>### Rationales E:  Soda Pop is much larger than a cupboard, and since Soda pop doesnt fit in your hand you need to eliminate any other choice which is much bigger than the cupboard<n><n>### A: Coffee does not fit in your hand, so you need to eliminate any choice which is larger than a cupboard.<n><n>### D: Chocolate, does not fit in your  hand because it is much larger, so you need to eliminated any choices larger than the cupboard.<n><n><n><n>### Input 0f the day: How many ounces of water does it take to completely fill a two and a half-gallon container? Choice(s):  A: 1.0 ounces  B: 2.5 ounces  C: 1.5 ounces D: 3.0 ounces E: 4.5 ounces<n><n>### Demontsraton: It takes 1 ounce because 2.5 - 1  = <<2.5-1>=1.5>><n><n>### Rationale: if your answer is A, It does not fit, becuase your answer is less than the total of the fraction, so the answer must be less than D.<n><n>### Input of the Day: Choose the mathmatical equation that is true about 999,999:<n><n>### Demorastion:<n><n>### Rationale: 999, 999  = 9 x 100,000, so for the problem to be true,<n>999,959,999 has to be greater than 1,000,001, because<n><n>### 1,001,000/1,000 = \frac{"1,001}{1000}" = <<1,001/1,00"="100>>, so the denominator should not be larger than the numerator, which is why you have to choose C

Write the question and plug \(25\).<n>  <n>  \ \(f\) (25) = \(f(25)\), \(35 = 25\)?<n><n>Above choice is 3<n><n>##### 3 (f(25)) = f(35)<n><n>4. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>```<n><n>What body of water is usually shallow water? Choice A: Lake B: Aquarium C: Pool D: Pond E: children's pools<n>```<n><n>### Output<n><n>#### A<n><n>B: aquariums<n><n>#### B<n><n>A: lake<n><n>#### C<n><n>D: pond<n><n>#### D<n><n>E: children's poools<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>#### C<n>(B)<n><n>Answer: A because<n><n>### Inputs:A 5-digit number is such that the sum of its digits is even and the difference of its digits are odd. The function should check for the given value in the array and if the array contains the given value, you should return the position where the value is found. If the array does not contain the value, return the position –1. An example of the function call would be “checkArray[0, 100]” (since the number one would be found at index zero). The array should be declared beforehand. If the value is not found in the array, you should return a list containing all of the indices where the value is not found. The list should be ordered in ascending order. I think you should use a for loop to traverse the array. I am sure there is another way but if you do something else let me know.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>###### #1:Write a program that uses the following function.<n><n>######  function checkArray2(array, num)<n>###### {<n>######     if int array[ ]<n>######     for (int i=0;i < len(arr);i++)<n>######     if arr[i] == num<n>######     return i<n>######     return -1<n>###### }<n>######<n>###### int num = 7;<n>###### int len = 100;<n>###### int* array = [1, 1, 2, 4, 5, 7]<n>###### print checkArray2(array, num)<n><n>### Result<n><n>###### 7<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input <n>> write a program that asks for a string s but does not consume it and uses only 1 line to create a substring like substring('xbc') is 'bc'. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:You might head to the locker room after getting a green drink here. Choices:  A: health club B: jocks C: fitness centre D: stadium E: gymnasium<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales: The gym is the best choice.<n><n>### Input:#1: If a basketball player wears an arm sleeve to cover tattoos, why is the sleeve only one-eighth as long as the player's arm? <n>#2: A player shoots a 3-pointer with a high rate of success, and he is on track to lead the nation in 3-point field goals this season<n>#3: What exactly is the difference between a slam dunk, a dunk, a jam, and a lay-up?<n><n>### Rationales: A player shoots 8 three pointers in a game with a success rate of 70%, which is 70/8=<<70/8=87.5>>87.5%. If he leads the nation in 3 point field goals, he must have shot a lot.<n>A slam dunk would be dunking into the basket very loudly.<n>A dunk is when your holding the ball over your head while dunking.<n>A jam is also dunking but very quietly.<n>A lay up is when you shoot near the hoop.<n>#### 8<n>Answer: 87.5<n><n>### Input:"Tony is the tallest kid in his class." "You are not as tall as Anthony." "It is easy for me to tie my shoes." These statements are what type of reasoning?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Another way to put it is "statements of fact".<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Those are all statements of fact. There is nothing they can do except argue with others.<n><n>### :8<n>Answer: Statements of fact<n><n>### Input>>Ann was a little tired after her work out that she decided to take a nap. While she was sleeping her phone started vibrating. When she finally woke up she had over 80 texts and 15 phone calls. The next day Ann felt horrible after a bad night sleep and realized she had been distracted because she was worried about all of the messages and calls she had received. What type of fallacy is being displayed by Ann?<n><n>### :<n>Rationales: This is called the fallacy called 'Red Herring'.<n><n>### :

In fruit market<n><n>2.1 - 10 = x = 6 – (10 – 0) => 6 – 6 = 0 – 6 = 6<n><n>

Noun phrases contain modifiers and can have verb phrases as their predicate. Complete the following sentences using a noun or prononu for the underlined phrase.<n><n>  -   **[A]**  It was a beautiful _____________.<n><n>  - **[B]**  I am interested in seeing the ____________ on the tour.<n><n>  -  **[C]**  The _______________ was very large.<n><n>  - [D] The group is waiting _______________.<n><n>  - **E]** She wanted to buy something _____________.<n>\end{code}<n><n>Comment: I have put example of your problem above with my changes, if you got your expected result then please mark answer (✓) if it's helpful.

Choices:  A: one material often recycled B: ripped C: saturated with water D: one dimensional E: crumpled<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>C: saturated with Water<n><n>### Input:\What can you do to stop a paper from getting saturated with water?<n>### Response: <n>A. If you want to stop a paper from absorbing water, use a plastic bag.<n>B. If you want to prevent a paper from getting wet, use a hard cover.<n>C. If you want to avoid getting a bacterial infection, use scissors to cut any sharp edges.<n>D. If you want to keep a paper from riping, use rubber.<n>E. If you want to make a piece of paper look beautiful, use a glue to make it shinier.<n><n>### Explantion:<n><n>### \Explanation:<n>A. If you use a plastic bag to contain a paper when it is wet, it won’t get wet anymore.<n>B. If a hard cover is used on a paper, the paper won’t get wet by water.<n>C. If a person with cuts on his hands use scissors or sharp objects to cut them, the chances of the cut person getting a bacterial would be minimal. For this reason, doctors advise people to use scissors to heal cuts.<n>D. If a paper gets wet, it may rip. To prevent the ripping of a paper or any other material that may get wet, an individual can use a rubber band <n>E. If a person want a piece of paper to look beautiful, they should use glue to make the paper to look more beautiful<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following questions.<n><n>Input: Which is better at holding moisture? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The president is the leader of what institution? Choices:  A: walmart B: white house C: country D: corporation E: government<n><n>### Response:		If the word was walmart, I would say it's a c store<n>If the word was national government, I would say it governed all countries.<n>#### A<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input<n>An investment adviser recommends purchasing 2 shares of XYZ stock for $25 and purchasing 3 shares at YZY stock for $35. Which one of the following statements is most likely true about the returns on these stocks in the second year? Choices: I: A and B would have the high returns. II: A would have a high return but b would not III: XYZ would have a higher return than YZY, but neither have a high return. IV: Neither XYZ or YZY will have a high return<n><n>### Response<n><n>If statement II, A would have a high but not B. If statement III, neither will have a high value, but both can make money. If statment IV, neither will make a huge profit but both are good. If the statement was A or B, that would mean both would have high return<n>#### II<n>Answer: III<n><n>### Input :<n>Four people split $120 evenly. You choose three balls from the bag. If you choose with replacement, what is the probability that:<n><n>A. you draw two red balls and one blue ball?<n>B. you draw at least two red balls?<n>C. you draw exactly three balls of the same color?<n>D. you draw at least three balls total?<n>E. You pick three balls that have one blue ball and two red balls?<n>F. you draw at least one red ball and at least one blue ball?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>For A:  (16/38) x (24/37) x (1/37) = 0.1608<n><n>For B: (16/37) x  (24/38) x  (2/38) = 0.3979<n><n>For C: (16/2) x (241/9) x (1/9) = 1/384<n><n>For D: (161/37) x   (24/3)  x (1/3) = 4/84<n><n>For E: (16/9) x  (25/9) x (362/9) = 0.4722<n><n>For F: =(16/37)*(24/37)*(1/37)<n><n><n>#### 0.16<n><n>Answer: 0.16

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you want to be able to earn money? Choices:  A: apply for job B: stand in line C: take care of proposals D: pass course E: play the lottery<n><n>### Response:		<n>The choice A is the right answer.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n><n><n>#### 1<n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>function readarray{<n>	declare -a array<n>	n=0<n>	while read a;do<n>		n=$[n+1];<n>		array[$n]="$a"<n>	done<n>	echo "${array[*]}"<n>}<n>	<n># $@ will get the command name<n><n>if [ $# -eq 0 ];then<n>	readarray -o<n>elif [ $# -eq1 ] && [ -z $1 ];then<n>	echo "No command"<n>	exit -1<n>else<n>	readarray "$1" #The parameter is the first one<n>	declare -p ${array[0]}		 #It's a way to print the varaibles of an array.<n>	echo "************************************"<n>	echo "${array[@]}"		 #The array is declared using the @ symbol, which will print all the indexes.<n>	echo "===================================="<n>	echo "Please input the line"<n>	readarray -n<n>```<n>* [ ] Write a program that will display all the members of a array.<n><n>**[x]  Write a program that will allow the user to search for a string in an given array.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/env bash<n>#$1 will get the command name and the [ ] signifies the array<n><n>a=$1[]<n>    for i in $a; do<n>        if [ "$i" = "$1" ]; then<n>            echo "found"<n>            break;<n>        fi<n>    done <n>```<n><n><n><n>### Questions:<n>* What would you do if you feel lost about the assignment?<n><n>* What would you ask to a staff or the instructor if the program doesn't work?<n><n>* What could be a possible error(s) if the program doesn' t work?<n><n><n><n>

Configure the code to include a response for each combination of items in the list.<n><n>### The problem that you write a program to perform the following calculation.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>First, 35 + 4 = <<35+4=39>>39, then 39 + 6 = <<39+6=45>>45, finally calculate 17 + 17, then 7 + 11, add, 18.<n>Output: 18<n><n>### Demostration :<n>R: Enter and compute the total sum of the elements in the list<n>Input : The list is <<35+4+17+7+6+11>>35+4+9+7<n>R: What are the two smallest numbers<n><n>### Demonsration :<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Solve each problem and complete the blank space in the program.<n><n>### Calls and Returns:<n><n>### R: Write a program to answer the following questions:<n><n>### Q: What value should not go into the parameter list of the recursive function to pass an argument as the first argument?<n><n>### Q.R: Write a program that determines and displays the largest and the smallest positive integers that are dividable by 11<n><n>### Demmonsration :<n>```python<n>def find_dividable(num):<n>    div = True<n>    for i in range(3, 12):<n>        if num % i!= 0:<n>            div = False<n>            break<n>    if div or num == 11:<n>        print(num, 'dividable with 11')<n>    else:<n>        print(2, num)<n><n>find_dividable(12)<n>find_dividabl(2)<n>```<n><n>## Output :<n>```12 dividable with

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:James felt himself losing consciousness.  He was frightened.  He didn't want this.  He was scared of what? Choices:  A: death B: coma C: peace D: forgetfulness E: loss of life<n><n>### Response:		<n>James was scared of what he was losing. He was losing consciousness. <n>Hence option A is correct answer.<n><n>### Input :  Write a letter or text message to a friend or teammate asking him or her to bring something. The friend or teammate is on an outing with his or her other group and has gone to the store without you. The letter should include the following:<n><n>### Demostration :<n><n>* Greeting<n>* Request<n>* Thank You<n><n>### Rationals:<n><n>* Request: I hope that you will be bringing some good books and I am excited to have a couple days of peace and quiet. <n>* Greeting:<n>Please bring books, some good books, which I am very glad that I have a couple days of good books.<n>* Thank you<n>* Your Friend/soccer teammate<n> 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:When you play around with your dog they will have? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He knows he needs at least two more chapters to create enough content. He knows that all the data he needs is stored on his internal hard drive. He also knows that all existing documents are saved in the cloud.<n>Write a program that will help Richard organize his thoughts. The program will:<n><n>Ask the user 1 question: The user will first confirm how many chapters are needed.<n><n>Output the following messages that inform the user what to do:<n><n>If 0 chapters are needed:<n>"Write a short thank you note and send it to the client."<n>If 1 chapter is needed:<n>"Write 1 complete and thorough chapter and send it to the cloud. Then start the process again."<n>If 2 or more chapters are needed: "You are all set. You will need to include how many chapters in the thank you note."<n><n>### What can the program do, assuming the question is answered as follows:<n>How many chapters do you need?<n><n>**0**<n>**1**<n>**2**<n>#### [0,12]<n>#### >2<n>How can you make the code more efficient?<n><n>Include a loop so the code can run in any other circumstance.<n>### The code above meets the requirements, but can also be more efficient.<n>Your job is to make it efficient, and this is expected to be the first draft.<n><n>### Write a short comment to explain how the program works and how it can be improved.<n><n>#### Sample program:<n>```<n>def writeChapters(chapters):<n>	answer = input("How many chapters do we need?\n")<n>	if answer == 0:<n>		print "write a short thank you note to the client"<n><n>	else:<n>		while True:<n>			if answer == 2:<n>				print "you're all set!"<n>			else:<n>	          print "you are missing " + str(answer + 1)<n>				answer = int(input("

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:If I had a jar which was likely to spoil if left out, where would I want to put it? Choices:  A: kitchen cupboard B: pantry C: grocery store D: pantry E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale: If I had a jar that is likely to spoil if I left it out, I would put it in the pantry because:<n>If I do not want to waste, the pantry is the best choice.<n>Putting the item in the kitchen cupboard would mean I would lose the item,<n><n>If I placed the item in the refrigerator, I would need to consume it sooner than I would have if I put it on the pantry,<n><n>The grocery store would be a lot of trouble because I would need to be going to the store every now and then.<n><n>The pantry would be the best option if I want to save my items for a long time.<n>####<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input The problem is to choose a color for a 500 yard stretch of roadway being painted. The color will be viewed from 21,000 feet above. What should you pick?<n><n>#### Color<n><n>Answer: White<n><n>### Rationales:<n>You want a color that will not create contrast. Since the viewer is 21,0<n><n>### 000 feet from the ground, you want the choice not to stand out.<n><n>If it stood out, the planes would not be able to land properly. That would put the life of many people at risk.<n><n>Which is what you would not want happening.<n><n>#### White<n><n>#### <n><n>#

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The man uses grooming before a job interview, what is he trying to portray? Choices:  A: looking good B: beauty C: tardiness D: handsomeness E: neatness<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Instruction answer: The answer of the question based on the rationales: Input:The man uses _______ before a job interview,what is he trying to portay? Choice A: looking good B :beauty C :tardiness D :handsome E :Neatness.<n><n>### Answer:<n>####  <n>### Demonstation answer:<n>### Instuction answer:<n>The answer of the question is: A.<n>\[A = >> "The job interviewee has to look good, to grab the interviewer's attention. This is achieved with use of accessories and proper grooming such as hair cut and well-matched attires." \]<n><n>### Demostration answer:<n><n>Input: The word bamboo is the only one in the dictionary to begin with the letter B. Which letter is B next to?<n>Rationales<n>Answer:  C<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The game was on sale. Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		<n>F: all of these <n><n>### Input A: The movie was 10% off.<n><n>### Response B: <n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>The game was on sale, and<n><n>because when you buy an item that can be bought for less, you save money when you buy it.<n><n>The movie was 10 % off.

Choices:  A: oklahoma B: university C: college campus D: players E: yard<n><n>### Response:		 The correct answer is B: university. A: Oklahoma and C: university campus are incorrect. C: college campus is wrong because a college campus can contain more than one university. D: Players would not be able to stand on a field. Also, a field is where the players play football, not a group of them. F: yard is possible but cannot be definitively called incorrect.<n><n>#### 10<n>Answer: B: university<n><n>### Input The population of the world in 2000 was roughly 6,148,849,825 humans. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The hippy wanted peace with all humans, he had strong what for them all? Choices:  A: names B: words C: naval D: bladders E: feelings<n><n>### Response:		<n>We find this question really interesting...<n>Our instinctual response is that they chose their names!<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. The hippy was a young man who lived in a park in San Francisco. 2. A group of young people visited the park where the hippy lived. 3. Some of the young people disagreed with the hippy. 4. The hippy said the people were all right. 5. The hippy had strong feelings for people in San Francisco. 6. The hippy also had strong feelings for people around the world. 7. How many strong feelings did the hippy have in all?<n>Rationales:(We don’t think there are “strong feelings” because they are either “strong” or “feelings”)<n>Feelings: He felt strong about all of the people he wanted to meet.<n>Naval: He didn’t want to fight with anyone.<n>### Answer:<n>Strong Feelings: 151<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What will telling many people about an embarrassing situation lead to? Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: notoriety<n><n>### Rationales:<n>In the example, the person who talked with the reporter was not famous or known, but he became famous. He became famous due to the rumors spreading around.<n>To sum up, telling the rumor leads to notoriety.<n><n>The response of this task is _notoriety_.<n><n>### **Additional Questions**<n>Input: If you’re not the fastest runner in your group, you’re among the slowest. Which of the following conclusions about your group is false?<n>Choices: A: Most of the members are not average runners.<n>B: The average runner is not the fastest runner. C: None of the members are slow runners.<n>D: The fastest runner is not among the group. E: The group’s average runner is slower than the average runner.<n>Output:<n>Rationales: Fastest runner is the top one because it is the definition of fastest. The top one runner should be slower than average one and the bottom one should be faster than average one. When you run with people, everybody run fast and everybody run slow. Only the slowest and the fastest are different from average runner. So, if the speed of the fastest runners is different from average runner, this means the average runner is one of the members of the group. And then we got _D_.<n>If the top fastness is the same as average runner, it means the fastest runner is not in the group. It means that among the slowest is the second fastest runner. Therefore, among the slowest is also the second fastest runner which means none of the members are slow runner. Because only the second fastest runner is among the slowest. If they are not slow runner then they are among fastest runners. And therefore, all are on the same level.<n>#### 7<n>Answer: None of the members is slow runners<n><n>When you want to solve this problem, remember these four main points.<n><n>1. If you are _among_ the slowest (not _the_ slowest), you must be fast.<n>2. Fastest runner is _the_ slowest runner<n>3. Average runner is not _the_ slowest<n>4. The second fastest runner is _not_ among the slowest.<n><n><n># 영역

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:James needed a garage because he spent a lot of money on what? I can’t imagine what it must be like for the victim to be attacked by a wild animal. I do have some sympathy for the wild animals being blamed for such attacks because there’s very little they can do to fight back. They are, though, blamed for such attacks, and that’s just sad.<n><n>My parents told me that there is an old adage about wild animals: “a sleeping dog is safe and sound.” I don’t find that to be a particularly appealing saying now or ever. If animals had the ability to sleep for a while, they would. An old joke about “sleeping dogs” is that the dogs who sleep most are mammals, and if an animal can’t sleep, it’s safe to assume that it’s not a dog.<n><n>Whenever the subject of “sleeping dogs” comes up, I’m reminded of an incident some years ago when a family’s dog was killed. The dog died sometime between when the owners went to work and when they came home. The dog was killed not because of a family member or something the dog did while the family was away, but because it stayed home alone after the family had gone to work. There are many good reasons why a dog should be kept indoors and that a dog should never be left alone at home for an excessive amount of time. I think these facts would make excellent topics for a future blog post or perhaps an article in the local paper.<n><n>### Question 1<n><n>Which choice is not a part of the passage?<n><n>#### 0<n>A. Choices:  A: bookstore B: house C: race track D: friend's house E: building<n><n>### Response:		A<n>#### A<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Your answer to each inquiry should be a minimum of 100 words.<n><n>### Topic 1:<n>- The role of variables in computer programming<n>- Explain what a variable is, and how a variable can be used in a program<n>- How is a variable defined?<n>- How are variables declared and assigned?<n>- How is a program able to identify a specific variable?<n>- What are the different data types, and what is their purpose?<n>- Provide an example where each data type would be used<n><n>Answer: A variable is an identifier that takes one or more values that may change. Programmers can use variables to store different values that are useful for a computer program. A variable name is an identifier that a computer program uses to describe where certain values will be stored.<n><n>Example: I have many variables, like my name and my age. These variables are not set to a specific amount in the beginning. They don't go into specific values that I have to set later on. They can change and use different values, and they can change whenever I want them to.<n><n>A computer program can use variables to keep track of different values that may be needed for the program later on. A computer program can set specific values for variables to help it to run better.<n><n>Example: The values in a program may be difficult to keep track of, or they may be repeated over and over again. This is why we create variables to store unique, different variables. We use values in variables so we don't write down the same value over and over for everything. This way, we use fewer lines of code when programming.<n><n>Computers don't know where in memory data goes unless you provide it with a value that specifically indicates where the data should be stored. For example, the "value" of a variable in a program is called its "address", and can be thought of as the address of that value and the specific address and location of stored data in memory.<n><n>Example: When I use a program, I don't know where the data goes, unless I am told what the specific address is. The data is stored somewhere in the memory or in a file on the computer. For example, when I save a picture using my camera, it creates a file on my computer, which is stored in the memory of my computer.<n><n>The most important

It also sells the balalaika but, the balalaika also sells an orchestra because it sells other instruments.<n><n>### Input:(10<2) AND ((10<1) AND (2<3)) What do we know? Choices:  a: 10 is a fraction c: 10 is an integer  c: 10 can divide by 0 b: 10 is not a fraction b: 10 can multiply by 0 b:2 is not a fraction<n><n>### Response:: 10 can divide 10. We also learn that 10 can multiply 10 but, it can’t divide by itself because it will be 10 over 0. That will be undefined or we also know that 10 can not divide 0.<n><n>### Rationales: We know that 10 is divisible by 10 because we know that we can divide 10 by itself and it is equal to 1. The answer is A: 10 is divisibe by 10.<n><n>## Rationales:<n>**Divide** <n><n>* If the divisor is larger then the dividet the answer is a remainder and when the dividend is greater then the divisor the remainder is a negative number.<n><n>* If the dividend is bigger then the divisor then the answer is a quotient in positive.<n><n>* If the the dividend is larger than the divisor the remainder will be 0.<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:<n>If she is standing in a forest, she is in Indiana. If she is standing in Illinois, she is surrounded by trees.<n>If she picked from an apple orchard, she is in Farmer's market<n>If she picked from a wood pile, she is in New York, as wood piles are not surrounded by other trees. The same happens with trees (farmers markets may be surrounded by other trees, and may not always be surrounded by other trees).<n>If she is in the bush, she is in Indiana or New York.<n>The answer is A = Indiana<n><n>Answer: A:New york<n><n>Input: Rules:<n>- Each shape has only one face.<n>- Faces can be concave or convex.<n>- A face can also be called a side.<n>Concave shapes have fewer sides than convex shapes. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What would children do if they are bored? The word "meet" might be confused with "meet" when it is pronounced as "miat." "Meet" is a noun, which means "a person who is present" or "a connection between two people." It is pronounced as "meeat." "Meat" is pronounced as "meyt." Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n><n>### Response:		Castle<n><n>[Explanation](https://github.com/nabeelahmed916/HW/blob/master/39.pdf)<n><n>### Input A: One of the possible inputs of a function is 3. Which of the following represents exactly what the input will become when it is used in the function?<n><n>### Response A: 27<n><n>[Explanatio](https://github.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What place is not interesting to children? Choices:  A: classroom B: toy store C: school D: soccer game E: dinner<n><n>### Response:		<n>Place: school<n><n>### Output:<n>Option: A<n><n>### Inputs & Output Types:<n>In the below instruction, you are given some text and an instruction that describes a sentence. Answer the question by completing the task.<n><n>### Input<n>The cows say: Mooo...<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>The cows are mad.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: mad<n><n>### Input & Output Types<n>In the below instruction your are given some text and and instruction that describes a sentence that is written in the form of a statement. Answer the question by appropriately completing the task. In the below sentence, you are given some statements and an instruction that describes two statements. Answer the question by combining the two statements.<n><n>### Statement<n>All kids need at least 90 minutes of sleep. Sleeping well makes kids more alert and energized, helps them think better, and improves their performance in sports and academics.<n><n>### Task<n>Combine the first statement with the first statement to create a new sentence.<n><n>### Outcome<n>In the below instruction you are given some statements. Answer the questions by completing the tasks.<n><n>### First Statement:<n>Kids who eat more fruits and vegetables sleep better.<n><n>### Second Statement:<n>Waking at the same time every day helps kids sleep better.<n><n>#### 50 minutes<n>Answer: <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:How can you get in shape if there is no land nearby? Choices:  A: swim B: jog C: excercise D: work out E: rock climb<n><n>### Response:		The only activity available is running.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>You can run on a treadmill if you have one.<n>You can run on the roof of a building.<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>A B C D E<n><n>### Response Rationales:<n>If you have no land, you need to find something other than running.<n>If you have no treadmill, you can still have running.<n><n>## Exercise 1.9: Factoring<n><n>##### Solving:<n>Write statements that correctly complete the task.<n>Input: If 3x – (3x + 4 ) = ?<n>Rationales: if (1)(2) = x then (3) = 2<n>If 3x = (3x + 3)<n>3x = (3 + 3)<n><n>14 <n>#### 122<n><n>Exercise 1.10: Evaluating Expressions<n><n>##### Solve:<n>Write a statement that correctly completes the question mark.<n>Input: If –4  + -6 = ? then  -4 + ______ =  –6<n>Rationales: -4*1+6*=-4+1=-12<n> -4+(-4 + -12) = -6<n><n>4<n>#### 4<n>Exercise 2: Factoring<n>##### Solve.<n>Write statements that correctly completes the task.<n>Input Choices: <n>2(x + 6) + 2( - x ) = 14<n><n>Exercise: Evaluating Express<n>##### Solve<n>Write statements that correctly solves each task.<n><n>12 + 31 = 2(6 + 17 )<n><n>#### 12 + 3(6 + 15) = 4<n>49<n><n>Exercise Solving for x<n> #### Solve for x<n><n> 24 – 4x = 8<n><n>x = 10.6<n><n>Answer: 10.6

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: deceptive B: altruistic C: stupid D: cruel E: agressive<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>Trait <n><n>```  <n><n>```python<n>if choice==A:    <n>    ans=True<n>elif choice==B:<n>    ans=False<n>else:<n>    ans=input("Please Choose A or B, Try Again")<n>ans=ans.split('/')  <n>print("Your Answer is: "+str(ans))<n>```<n>### Output:<n>```python<n>    Trait <n><n>    Please Choose A or B<n><n>```<n>#### E<n>    Your Answer is: ['E']<n>```python<n><n>```

During a four month period they spent $75. What was the profit?<n><n>#### _Rationales_<n><n>* Hurleys money was $75 because Hurley lost money 3 months ago<n>* Pablo money was $30 because Pablo saved 65$ for three months<n><n>#### _Response_<n><n>#### _Answer_: Pablo had $30, Hurley had $75, $105-75=56 <n>$135 - $75 = $105<n>$105 - $56 = $49

Write a response that describes your thinking in a manner that is fair and reasonable.<n>Rationales: Because I think it is 2 nights from 2/3 and her friend thinks it is 4 nights from 4/3, my friend thinks what I think and she thinks what I think so she needs to come with me<n><n>#### What do you think : C B C F E D<n><n>#### D B F D D F A<n><n>#### B D F D F D C<n><n>#### A D F F A F E<n><n>Answer : A<n><n><n>### Input  : You bought some strawberries on 2017-4/6 that were marked expired 2017–5/7. The date in a given month is: Month = Numeral of the day in the month; e.g., May = 5 and year = 2017 = 201*7 + l7 = (26 * 7) + 17 = 175<n>Ratalnes : In 2015 the day in month = 26 + 7 = 33<n>In 2017 the day in month = month + 1 = 5 + 1 = 6<n>In 207 the day in month= month + 1 = month + 2 = 6+2 = 8<n>In 209 the day of month = month +1 = month + 3=(3 + 2) = 5<n>In 206 the day in month =month + 1 = month and the expiry will be 07/01 because the month is 07<n>In 208 the date will be 08/01 and expires on 07/07<n>In 08 the date will 08/04 and expires on 7/08<n>Answer: May 8, 2017<n><n><n>### Instructions:In 2019, write an expression

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. What is the population after 7 years?<n><n>### Rathenal:<n>Population after 7 years = (3+3)+58%*3 = 5 years<n><n>### Answer:<n>3n-3+58%*3n = 5n+114<n>### Answer: 328<n>### Input: In an upheaval at the ice cream factory, the number of scoops of ice cream has increased from 7 to 15. The percentage of increase is what number greater than 50%?<n><n>### Input 15 scoops of icecream<n><n>\(15 \cdot 100/7 \% \) = 50%<n><n>### Input How many miles in 24 hour period.<n><n>### Response.<n><n>If I walk 2 miles an hour = 2<n>If I run 4 miles an hour = 8<n>It will be (2 + 8)miles = 10 miles<n><n>It will be (4 + 16)miles = 20 miles<n><n>It is possible for two people to walk at same miles per hour?<n>\(2 × 2 = 10\)<n>\(24 – 2 \:

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The other passengers on the bus were quite loud, so he put on his headphones to relax and what? Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		 the correct answer is A<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Passengers who are on the bus are quiet.<n>So, he put on his headphone to relax which means A.<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>A: {Headphone is a wearable audio device that you put on your head to play audio.}<n>B: {Sleep is a state of body and mind, the physical condition of being asleep.<n>        Sleep is a natural state of lowered consciousness and relative immobility that occurs in most vertebrates, including mammals, birds, and many reptiles.  }<n>C: {Music is sounds, combinations of musical tones which are performed by musical instruments, singers, or speakers in musical works with one or more musicians.  }<n>D: {Stretch out is stretching and extending a part fully or partially until it is straight, in order to lengthen it or to make it flexible. }<n>E: {Stop worryinig is the act of having or expressing anxieties or fears. }<n><n>####  A<n>Answer:  A<n>### Instruction 4:A.What is the value of 1,000 x 5?<n>Rationales : If 1,00x five is 5,000 so 5000/1000 = <<5000/500=10>>10<n><n>5 times 1k  is 5k<n><n>#### 10<n>Answer: 5k<n>### Instruction1:Write the subtraction equation.<n>### Demonstation:<n>12 - 3 = <<12-3=9>>9<n><n>#### 9<n>Answer: 9<n>

How many days did each team take to plow each yard.<n><n>### Rationales: <n>If both of the teams are plowing yarden together.<n><n>Let m1 = teams who took 1day to plow 1acre per 1day. and m2 = >>>>>>>m1<<<<<<<<<n>After 4days of plowing, in total we should have >>>>>total(m1+m2+…+m1)<<<<<<<<n>Because it’s the total of the distance that team 1 and 2 covered in 4days or we may say<n>it’s the total of 4days of total distance that was covered by team 1 on 1day and team 2 also on 1day<n><n>Let m* = total distance that was covered in 4days.<n>So, >>>>>>total(m1+…+m1)=4<m*>>>>>><n>After solving this we get >>>>>>4<m*>>>m*>>>>>> m*=4<n>Here we are trying to say team 1 and team 2 started plowing together. So, we divide the m1 and m2 to a team in one day to plow 1 acre<n>So (m1+m2)/2= m1/2 and.m1/2 = 1<n><n>So 2( m1/2) = > m1<n><n>Answer that i gave>> >>4x 2=8<n><n>### Input and Rationales:<n><n>>A farmer has two<n>teams of mules who can<n>plow a field one yard<n>at a time.
