Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Lindy was a senior.  He lived with his children because he didn't want to go where? Choices:  A: republican party B: old people's home C: office D: park E: high school or college<n><n>### Response:		 A: republic party B: old people"s home C: office<n><n>### Input 2:Juan and Joe had two different methods of finding the answer in a lesson on finding the least common multiple. Juan divided all the numbers in the multiples list by the first number and then subtracted the resulting number with the product of all the numbers. On the other hand, Joe multiplied all the numbers in the same list and then subtracted the largest of the products with the product of the first numbers. Which way was more effective?<n><n>### Rationales:  Joe"s way is more effective.<n><n>### Answer:Joe"s way.

Choices:  A: being happy B: glee C: smoke D: stress relief E: may laugh<n><n>### Response:		The only correct answer is E. All the others sound stressful.<n>__Answer__: All the other answers sound stressful except<n><n>### Demonsrtion:<n>input a: being happy;<n>Rationales: being happy is not stressful.<n>b: glee;<n>Rationalesg: glee would stress you out.<n>c: smoke;<n>Rationalesis: smoking would stress you out. Sounds strangely positive?<n>d: stress relief;<n>Rationaless: stress relief is not fun, just the opposite.<n>e: may laugh<n>Rationales: laughing will be fun.<n><n>#### CORRECT:e<n>Answer: e<n><n><n>### Input The following is true or false.<n><n>### Responses:<n>- The correct answer is TRUE.<n>- The following input is false:<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input: The following input is true or false. Is this the case? The sum of two odd numbers times a positive integer is odd.<n>Rationales: In order for the sum of two odd numbers to be odd, they would have to be odd numbers. Odd is a factor of odd. Since a positive integer is a whole number, the sum of two even numbers must be even.<n>An even number must evenly split a positive integer since a positive integer is a wholly even number.<n>Input is false because: It is not true that the sum of two odds is odd if they were even numbers.<n>#### FALSE<n><n>### Demostration:<n>input: The sum of two odds times a positive integer is even<n>Rationales: The sum of two even numbers times a positive integer must be even. Odd is a mathematical operation to make even an even value. Positive integers are not odd since they are whole and even.<n>The sum of two odd numbers must be even because they're both odd and evenly combined.<n>If both odds had different numbers, one would have to be converted to odd before the sum could be odd.<n>#### Even<n>answer: False

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a bag after someone fills it with clothes? Choices:  A: shopping cart B: cashier C: shopping mall D: supermarket E: bookstore<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```C```<n><n>### Notes<n><n>You're probably missing the last answer, but this is how to check if a bag is returned:<n><n>Check if the bag is located at a supermarket.<n>If it is, exit to the bag.<n>If it is not, check if the bag is located in some store, namely, a cashier.<n>If it is a cashier, exit to the bag's location.<n>If it is another location, go to the baggage claim screen.<n>If you are in the same location, repeat the procedure with the bag.<n>If you find a bag in a bookstore, return back to the last screen.<n>### Demonstoration:<n>**First case**<n>Input: Let's check whether we get a bag after our clothes are stuffed into it by someone.<n>Choices: B, C, E<n>Output: C<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>**Case 2**<n>Input: Let us suppose the bag is located in a bookstore.<n>Choices: A, D, E<n>Output: A<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>**Case 3**<n>Input: Let’s check if our bag is located in a cashier. No, it is not. What would we do next?<n>Choices: E, O, S<n>Output: O<n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>**Case 4**<n>Input: Let's check whether the bag is located in the baggage claim. Yes, it is.<n>Choices: S, S, S<n>Output: P<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>**Case 5**<n>Input: If it's a bookstore, return to the previous screen. Next, we will go to the screen where we need to put everything and then choose the item "C".<n><n>### Note<n><n>### Demostration:<n>**First Case**<n>Input: Let&#39;s check whether we get to a bag after someone stuffs our clothes into it.<n>Choices: `B`, `C`, `E`<n>Output: `C`<n>#### **3**<n>Answer: 38<n><n>**Second Case**<n>Input: Suppose the bag has been lost.<n>Choices: `&lt;B&lt;`, `&lt;C

Below is a task that represents the request to demonstrate the steps of work process for answering a multiple choice question. Write a response that identifies the work processes for answering a multiple choice questions. The request is written above.<n><n>### Note : Below are instructions to complete the task.<n><n>Demonstration: The difference in ages of Richard and Hurley is twenty years.<n>If Hurley is 13 years old, in how many years will their combined ages be twice as much as Richard is 35 years old?<n><n>### Instructor Respons:<n><n>Ask the student:<n>“What steps must the student do?”<n>A. 1)Find the difference between Richard age and Hurley<n>2) Find the addition between the Hurley age and 20<n>5)Divide result by 15<n>A<n><n>### Instuctions<n><n>In this task you will practice writing responses based on the requests that may have been skipped or incorrect in class. Below is a request that may have been skippped or incorrect during class. After analyzing each response, select the option that is the best response to the request.<n><n>1. Choices: A: 1/6 B: 2/6 C: 3/6 D: 4/6<n>Answer: A: 1 / 6<n><n>### Input Answer the following multiple choice questions<n>> Input: You are buying a house that has 4 bedrooms, 2 toilets, 3 bathrooms, and 15 doors. You have $140000 to spend on both furniture and installation costs to make the house habitable. Which is the best use of your money? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What chore might a child have to do after breakfast, before getting on the bus? Choices:  A: drop out of school B: ask questions C: enter school D: wash dishes E: read book<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>#### 12

Below is an instruction that describes a task. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Everybody raised a drink and cheered, they were doing what? Choices:  A: were thirsty B: toasting C: getting drunk D: refreshment E: celebrating<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Reason: Choices: A and D<n><n>#### 511<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input<n>A) <n>Rationales: The answer is A.<n><n>C)<n>Rationales: B is for birthday<n><n>E)<n><n>Rationales: We celebrate every Christmas and Easter but we have two Birthdays everyday not just one.<n><n>B)<n><n>Rational: 	 A birthday is once every year. There are 365 days in one entire year. Birthdays occur on the day in which a person was born, not a person's number of days born. For example, if you are born in January, you would be one year old each birthday.  If you are born in July, you would be 3 or 6 years old each birthday, but the same amount of days have passed. This is because you were more than one year old the day you were born.  If you are an adolescent, it is a birthday if you are the age to drink alcohol now, but the same amount months have passed since you were born as the birthdays you celebrated a year ago. For example, if it took you 18 years to go from a child into an adolescent where drinking is permitted to a child, you would not be a year older for the first year, but you would the next. This is because it took more than a year for you to go from a child to an adolescent.  This is true every year and you would have to divide one year by 365 to know when it is a birthday.<n><n>F)<n><n>Rationals: The only ones that fit are E and F. They both are the only ones that are more than one year older.<n><n>#### 595<n>Answer: C)<n><n>### Input <n>A)What is this word made of letters <n><n>Input:<n>Rationales: A is for Apple<n><n>B) What is this word made of words ____ and _____?<n>Input:<n>Rationales: The answer is C. A dog and a puppy.<n><n>C) <n>Input:<n><n>Rationales : The answer is D because of the period in the 4th position of every word.<n><n>####589<n>Answer: D)<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:He got a job dancing and waving an advertisement, he got to be outside instead of stuck inside the what? Choices:  A: advertisement B: magazine C: store D: web page E: bus<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n>### Response:<n><n>#### 1<n><n>### Input,Demonstration,and Response:<n><n>Input<n>```<n>227-175 <n>```<n><n>#### 232<n>```<n>299/29 <n>```<n>Output<n>```<n><n>10.9 <n>```<n><n>### Demostration, and Answer<n><n>Demonstration<n>```<n><n>286 <n>```<n><n>Answer<n>```<n>20 <n>```<n><n>In a store,<n><n>```<n>484 <n>```<n><n>```<n>2 * 240 <n>```<n>```<n>180 <n>```<n>### Calculations<n><n>```<n>398 / 6 = 64 <n>```<n>Input<n>```<n>397 + 98 * 3 =?? <n>```<n><n>Output<n>```<n>493 <n>```<n><n>Input<n>```3 26 - 23/3 <n>```<n>```29/3```<n>```36```<n>### Calculation <n>Input<n>```<n>(15 x 28) + (18 x 25) <n>```<n><n>137<n>```300```<n>```1999```<n><n>### Input <n><n>```10 * 11 + 11 * 6 =?```<n><n>Output<n><n>```77```<n><n>### Example<n><n>```<n>56 <n>```<n>```56 <n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where does someone lay with their leg elevated when it's broken? Choices:  A: spinning wheel B: on a ladder C: hospital bed D: legroom E: grand piano<n><n>### Response:		Legroom is the word.<n>

If Sam earns $8.50 an hour, what is the minimum-wage Sam needs to make to meet his saving goal?<n>Rationales-If he needs to save 75%, he needs to save $6.375.<n>Forty hours is 75% of 8.5<n>$6.375 / 40 = <<6.375/40=0.16>>0.16<n><n>He would need to make minimum wage to save that.<n>Answer: 11.20<n><n>### Input<n>**Alice:** Did you know that two is prime?<n><n>**Bob:** Really? In what sense?<n><n>#### A: There are exactly two prime numbers between 2 and 5.<n><n>#### B: You don' t have to be a mathematician to calculate that 2 + 3 = 5.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Alice.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>- A: Two is prime in the sense that two is NOT divisible by any other number. 5 is also prime in that sense, because neither 2 NOR 3 can divide 5.<n>- Bob: In the sense that "You don't have to be a math student to calculate that 5 = 2 + 3". Bob also points ot he number sentence of the same question he asked<n><n>### Input  <n>**Alice: **I don't know the square root of 2.<n><n>**Bob: **You're smarter than some square root of a certain number.<n><n>#### A: You probably know the square root of a certain other number.<n><n>#### B. : I'll get my calculator.<n><n>#### C: 0.707107 + 0.700700 = 1.407700<n><n>#### D: But you'll never be as smart as a root.<n><n>### Response  <n><n>**Alice**<n><n>### Rationales<n>- A: Alice can square one and solve for r(which can be converted to a decimal then multiplied by 2 in the form 2

Choices:  A: lot of grief B: depression C: no spouse D: lose money E: children suffer<n><n>### Response:		 A<n>#### A<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Someone getting divorced may cause a lot of grief and lose a lot of money.<n>Children don’t suffer like the spouse does.<n><n>If the spouse is getting a settlement, then they won’t have to worry about losing money,<n><n>They can find another place to live,<n><n>They can apply for government benefits.<n><n>A divorce isn’t as detrimental to a divorcee’s life as it is to a child’s life.<n><n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input : What are some similarities and differences between a book and a video game?<n><n>### Demosstration:<n>Input : Video games require interaction to complete an entire game, while books don’t necessarily.<n><n>Video games usually have a main quest, and a book can have multiple quests.<n>Some books can be used to replace video games that are no longer available, while video games are one and don’t get replaced by others.<n>A video game requires that the customer read the manual, where books don’t.<n><n>#### Similarities:<n><n>#### 1. Interaction vs no interaction<n><n>#### 2. Quest<n>#### 3. Purchasing a video game is permanent and costs more or less forever<n><n>#### Differences:<n>####1. The manual<n><n>####2. Replacing the game<n>####3. Time taken to complete<n><n>####3.<n><n>### Simularities : <n><n>#### 1: A book and a video game both require interaction to complete.<n><n>#### 2: A book doesn't necessarily have a main quest. a video game does.<n><n>#### 3: Video games are one and don't get replaced by others, whereas books aren't.<n>#### 4: A video game requires that the user read the manual<n><n>#### Differances:<n><n>####1: The cost of each type of media is permanent and lasts for a long time<n><n>####2: An interactive story is not just a video game, but rather an alternate way to consume a book.<n><n>### D.<n>Answer: A<n>

He loved the idea of going to mars, and reads books about it all the time.   He dreams of being on what? Choices:  A: love B: zoo C: school D: space shuttle E: library<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>#### A<n><n>#### B<n><n>#### C<n><n>#### D<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Input<n>Four men and five women are going on a trip together. They decide to choose team captains to divide and distribute the expenses among the group. One man in the group agrees to pay for the gas while one woman agrees to pay for meals. The other woman agrees to buy the snacks to share and the group’s remaining one man and one woman agree to equally split the remaining costs. The only condition to this is that two people from the same household are not allowed to pay for any expenses together. Who paid for the lodging?<n>Rationales Each person must pay for at least one expense. There are six different people, so one person, on the team, paid for each expense. Three people are female, and three people are male, so the following chart shows who paid for what.<n>The two men who split the lodging paid for lodging because they are the only two males on the trip.<n>The two women who split the lodging also paid for meals because they are the only females on the trip.<n>Three people can equal six and two people can equal 1 so one person, the group’s remaining man, paid for the lodging.<n>No two people shared the same household, so every person paid for at least one expenses.<n><n>#### The hotel<n><n>#### Meals<n><n>#### Snacks for sharing<n><n>#### Gas<n><n>#### Lodging<n><n>#### The meals<n><n>#### The lodging<n><n>#### The remainder<n><n>#### Lodgings<n><n><n><n>The group’s remaining man and the group’s other man agreed to split the remaining expenses equally by paying half, for a total of two per person, and one woman paid for the snacks. There is two people in every household so the gender cannot decide who paid for what. This is because each family is one person and the one person cannot choose who is male or female. For example, if D and E were a married couple, they could pay for the meals, just like how it was done. This problem is the way it is because the man and the woman agreed to pay for the other household’s expenses, instead of paying for every household’s expenses evenly. For example, if the male paid for gas and lodging he
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: rural area B: big city C: suburbs D: ohio E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		I'm going to start off by reading the four possible answers and I'm going to eliminate B. Ohio would be much too small to contain a large village. Countryside, by definition, would not contain a large village. So, that leaves us with ABCD. Now, I'll go about eliminating those options one by one. A: urban areas typically don't contain villages. Suburbs are an area found in many metropolises.<n><n>C: I'm going to have to eliminate C, because I know for sure that there are many villages located throughout the countryside, which would render it a choice.<n><n>B: I know Ohio has a lot in its cities, but big cities have so much activity that it's possible villages might be overlooked in the chaos.<n><n>D: Ohio is more like a countryside than a village. As you'll remember, villages contain smaller areas of activity. I'm going to say that they're not likely to find a village in Ohio. This leaves us with A and E because they're the only two that remain. However, I'm going to choose C as the correct answer because I'm going to explain why it's better than the other possible choices. Suburban areas are defined as regions surrounding a city. As the region grows more compact, villages may start popping up within the city itself. A: I'm going with B as the correct response because Ohio is more countryside than it is urban. It's not a village.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: B<n>#### 1<n>Answer: C<n>#### 3<n>Answer: E<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where did the person have to walk downstairs to get the tool? Choices:  A: hardware store B: basement C: garage D: repair shop E: the library.<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A is the best answer. He had to walk to the hardware shop.<n>

If Sam’s age is six years greater than twice the product of Sam’ s age and four times the sum of four and three times his age, how old is Sam?<n>Rationales : If the sum of 4 + 3 Sam's age = 7<n>then 7 + 2(4 - 3) = 21<n>Then 6 years greater = 21 + 6 = 27<n>Now 21 + 4(1/4)(27) = 31 + 101/4 = 51 + 77 / 4 = 128/4 = 32<n>Then the difference between Sam's age and 35 = (6+32) - 32 = 38 + 32 = 62<n>So 62 + 5 = 67<n>Then Sam's age =67-6+3 = 64<n>#### 64<n>Answer:64<n><n>### Multiple Choice Instruction-Answer the following multiple choice quesetion.<n><n>### Demo:<n>In each of the following, a figure is constructed by joining four, five, or six pieces in a particular manner, and then the figure is flipped over. Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		(D-Pantry)<n><n>### Input-Demonstration:<n>Input I: I need to find the value of $2n + $5$<n><n>Input II: -3 x 5 = <<-3\cdot 5=-15>>-15<n><n>Rationales: -3($n + 5) = <<-3\{(n + 5)\}=-3n-15>>-3n-135(<n><n>$\frac{2-5}{2-5} + 2n = -3n-15$<n><n>-3n + $ = <<-3n+15=12>> 12n<n><n>$\frac{-3n -15}{3}$n = <<-\frac{12n}{3}=12n\frac{-5}{3}>>12n\frac{5}{3}= <<12n\frac{\frac{5}{3}}{12n\frac {5}{3}}=-\frac{5}{-12n \frac {5}{3}}=\frac{5*12n}{3*5}=24>>24<n><n>I made $2a + 5b = b$n = <<2b\+5b=-5b=\frac{5}{2}(-b)=-\frac{5}{2}-b=-2b>>-2b<n><n>-2b = <<-2-b\=\frac{5}{3}-b=\frac{5*3}{-3}-b=\frac{-5+15}{-3}b=\frac{3*3}{-3}b=3>>3<n><n>So I would do -2($2n + 5$n) = <<-2(2n+5)n=-2n+10n=-3\frac{n}{-2}=-\frac{n-5}{-3n}\frac{n}{-3n}n-n=-12+\frac{n}{-12}n>>-\frac{n*-12}{-12}<n><n>I chose $n = 25$ because -$$\frac{-[-$12+\frac{25}{25}\frac{n}{n-12}]}{-12} = -125\frac{n}{n}$$and

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. What some people may not know is that these gems also sit near a river called the Colorado River.<n><n>* It’s the second-longest river in the contiguous United States.<n>* It stretches over 1,400 miles across the region between the Dakotas and the southwest.<n>* The Colorado River is believed to be one of the first rivers to have water that originates from snowmelt.<n><n>The Rio Grande River flows from Colorado to Texas and then continues on to the gulf of Mexico.<n><n>#### E <n><n>Rio Grande River<n><n>## #Task:Complete each statement.<n><n>### Input : I was planning to run a 100-yard dash when a tornado appeared. I began to run to the closest building. However, I did not get to the building before the tornado reached me.<n><n>### Response : The word "I" in the following sentence does not mean:<n><n>### The word "I" used in the sentence above does not mean<n><n>- Answer:  I refers to a person. This can be a single entity or a composite of individuals.<n><n>### Answer:  I refers all the people, things, or concepts involved in an action or activity mentioned.<n><n>### In math, is a number that is greater than 1. A prime number is divisible only by one and itself. A composite number is divisible by more than two different numbers.<n><n>### If a prime number is divided by two, it will yield a unique remainder

The word “one” sounds like it is counting fruit in some format. Grape and grapes can indicate the quantity or the specific type of fruit.<n>To chop something means to cut something with a sharp object, typically into smaller slices. The following terms for fruit are given.<n>1. (A) refers to “chop us” with fresh fruit. This refers to a quantity and not a specific fruit.<n>2. (B) refers to “chope” wine (press). The “press” in this case refers to a fruit basket.<n>3. (D) refers to “chore” a fruit cocktail. A fruit cocktail is often a combination of different fruits and typically is served in a liquid.<n>4. (E) refers to “choper” a picnic basket. This tells you the quantity is a large quantity with multiple variations of fruits.<n>```<n>Grape (D):<n>Fruit (A): <n>Chop us(A): <n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:James was a student who had a report that is due tomorrow.  Where might he spend most of his time today? Choices:  A: university B: college class C: class room D: classroom E: library<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Input:James was a student whose report is due tomorrow. Where might he spend most f his time today?<n>Choice A: James was in university.<n>Choice B: The classroom.<n>Option C: The classroom. It should be that James spent most of his time in the classroom.<n>Option E: The library. James spent most of his day in the library.<n>Option D: The Library. It should not be so because, there are no students in the library.<n><n>#### 6. B<n>Answers: 6. B<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is a fast but expensive way to send small cargo? Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Your response should be in the form of paragraphs. Read the following examples thoroughly to see how the process of writing and answering works.<n>---<n><n>### Instructions:Write your response in the Comment Form. Your response should be in paragraph form, not a bullet point. If you have any questions about the task, put your questions in the Comment Form as well.<n>---<n><n>\<n>### Instruction Example:<n><n>#### Parsing Information<n>Input and Rationale<n>Input: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>Rationales:<n><n>#### 12 Answer:<n><n>12<n>If Pablo read<n>12<n>books<n>12<n><n>## Example of the Process<n>Parsing Instructions (Input)<n>In the example above, the first sentence tells us that we need to write a response that is in paragraph form in order to appropriately answer the question.<n><n>Rationales<n>Rationale: If Hurley is<n>14<n><n>40 years from now, Hurleys will be 14<n>40 years from<n>74<n>Now, we have the information we need. As you can see, we start reading the question by breaking the two parts up into “Parsing” them. The first part is the information the task will tell us and what parts of the task we need to work on. The second part is the directions given in the task. The directions let us know what to do so we can “parse” the question properly.<n>Gathering Information and Gathering All of the Information<n>We gather our information by making a list of everything we know or read. In other words, we have to read and re-read the passage to gather all relevant information. In some cases, that means reading and re-reading again before writing any response. That is completely normal because we also have to determine what we do not know. In the case of a question like “What is the fastest way to get from New York to California?”, the key piece of information is “fast”. We would not want to make a decision about this question without determining that “speed” was required.<n><n>Writing<n>Once we know all the information we need we can “write” our response. Keep in mind, our response to any task will always include:<n>- The complete question stated.<n>- Our answer to the question.<n>- Any instructions on how to answer the question<n>Now

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Why would a company be going public? Choices:  A: revealing information B: being ridiculed C: problems D: more funding E: telling all<n><n>### Response:		The best choice for the company to go public is E:Telling all, because by going public, companies provide information on their financial status to the public.<n><n>### Input Choices:  A B C D E<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>You can ask about the above instruction and how to write response:<n><n>* If the input was "Input: Why would a company be going private? Choices: A: Revealing information B: Being ridiculed C D: More funding E: Telling all."<n>then you must write: <n>`Input: Explain why a company gets ridiculed or be private. Choices: A: More funding B: Being ridiccold C D: Revealing information E: Telling all.`<n><n>### Input<n>The company decided they should go public because their revenue is up 12%, their costs are down 5%, and their product sales are 8% ahead of projections. The executives decided they should begin working towards an Initial Public Offering.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Input: Explain why the company should go or not. Choices: A. Revealing Information B. Having Problems C. Getting More Funding D. Going Public <n>Rationales:<n>The company decided they would go public because their reorganization has been successful because of these reasons:<n><n>* Their revenue is up 5%, their costs are down, and their product sales are ahead of projections because they are more efficient.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What do people look for when competing against someone? Choices:  A: edge B: desire to win C: friendship D: rivalry E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: Option D, A, and B are unacceptable choices. Rivalry and friendship are both too personal to be of benefit. Skill is a necessity but will only lead to performance improvements if it is put to the test in competition. One possible way for a competitor to improve skill is to be competing.<n><n>**Reference:**

Choices:  A: town B: conference C: bathroom D: theater E: train station<n><n>### Response:		Option E<n><n>### Instructions: Answer all three of the following questions.<n><n>### Question #1: How many weeks are in 28 days? How many weeks are in a normal year? How many weeks are there in 3 months?<n><n>### Question#2: You are 30% below minimum wage for a 40 hour week. If you bill an hour, what is your total for the week?<n><n>### Answer: <n>If you work for 40 hours, you are 30% of 40 = <<30% of 30=40>>40 below minimum wage. That means for a 40- hour week (40/40=1) you are 30/40=$0.75 below minimum wage.<n>####0.75<n>Answer: <40+0.75 =<<40+0.25=40.75>>40.75<n><n>If you billed 2 hours per day that is 2 x 2 weeks = <<2 x 2 weeks=4>>4 billable hours.<n><n># You work an extra hour every week for overtime. Calculate your total earnings for 1 week, then for 3 months.<n><n>### Response #3:<n><n>### Question:<n>You earned $182.50 for that week.<n>#### 182.5<n>Answer: 182.0<n><n>### Question How many hours did your week end up being??<n>You got $140.00 + $182.00 = << $140+ 0182.0>182.0 of extra hours.<n>### Answer:<n><n>3 months = <<3Months=100>>100 weeks. You work 8 hours a day, and have to work extra for 110001 days, but have 1 month week endings instead of 7. So your 11001-11101- day weeks =<< 1100x 1 days=107 days>>107 work days. You worked 1 extra day for 3 days.<n>#### 107<n>Answer: 107<n><n>###

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The keys were black and white, what were they attached to? Choices:  A: front pocket B: cabinet C: purse D: chain E: piano<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demandation:Which color is bigger? Choices: A: Black B: White<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A->Black = <A: "black and white" > and B-> White = <<A: "black and" + "white">>Black<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blanks to create a sentence.<n><n>### ____:The keys were black ____.<n><n>B->White = <<B: "The keys were white">>black<n><n>1) Black and White = <<"Black and" + "White">>White<n><n>### Demostration:<n>### Rationale 2:<n><n>### B-> Black = <<B: "black and white";B: "white">>black<n><n>### Rationales: The keys were black and White = <<"black and white">>Black<n>The keys were white = <<"white">>black<n> <n>### Instruction :Complete the following sentence.<n><n>## Instruction:Fill in the missing blanks to complete the sentence.<n><n>## Demonstration:Basketball = [<<[A: Basketball];A: Basketball],[<<[A: Basketball]*A: Basketball>>]! basketball<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What do you need to run after ball? Choices:  A: get tired B: have legs C: skip D: not fat E: look first<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:<n>D. not fat<n><n>### Explanation<n>D is the answer.<n><n>### Rationale<n>D is the answer because ball needs to have legs to run

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The police man was waving flares, what did he do with the impatient car? Choices:  A: book robber B: he had a word with the driver. C: believe guilty D: direct traffic E: wave on<n><n>### Response:		<n>The rationales for your responses would be:<n><n>#### E<n>The answer is E because a policeman waving flares means to make traffic move, while an impatient car means they want the police to move on. Hence, the police should move on instead of giving a talk.<n><n>#### D<n><n>The answer is D because when a policeman is waving his flares, he's signalling them to the direction they're supposed to take instead of directing them to stop.<n>- You can't choose B because the driver was not impatient.<n>-You can't choose C because the police man didn't believe him to be a thief.<n>-You can choose A because he booked the car.<n><n>#### D is the answer<n><n>#### A<n><n>A is the answer because the word waving flares means the policeman wants the people to stop. It can't be B because it would just mean directing the traffic, which we can't give as an answer since the question said otherwise.<n><n>#### B<n><n>B isn't correct since what it says is that the policeman said some words with the driver, which isn't enough to book the car. Choices are either B, D, C, or A.<n><n>```<n>-------------------------------------------------------------------<n><n>### Input : 5000 people 10 cars each with 150 mpg, 400 people, 32 gas stations, 30 cars each with 200 mpg, 6400 gallons gas, 46 gas stations, 1 gallon,5 gallons, 8 miles, 25 cars each with 300 gallons gas.<n>```<n>```<n><n>### Answer : (1)7000 car, (4)65665 (5)162.5  (6)107.5<n>```

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would you hear a viola along side many other string and brass instruments? Choices:  A: symphony B: band C: create music D: orchestra E: string quartet<n><n>### Response:		Choice B because the viola is a type of string instrument and that's what your hearing in a band.<n><n>Demonstration: You are hearing a symphony band at the high school. The Viola is a string instrument and brass instruments are more commonly heard in bands. String instruments include violin, viola, cello, bass, viola, and many more. Brass instruments include trumpet, trombone, tubas, french horns, baritone horns all the way to saxophone. These instruments are commonly heard in symphonies and orchestras. Bands consist of drums, woodwind, and brass instruments.

Answer: 184<n>### Rationale The general formula for finding the n(20th) term is: n(20thTerm) = a(n + 1)/(m + 1)<n>Solving for n, we get: n = 183. Write a response that completes the task.<n>- Demonstration:Input:If a school bus has 51 students on a Monday from Monday to Thursday, the school bus must carry at least ________ students.<n>Rationales:If the bus has  51 students on Monday to Thursday a total of 4 days, at least __ students need to be on the bus.<n>Bus is a group ___> = <<4x51>>451<n>Bus needs to carry __> = <<4x18>>36 minimum number.<n>Bus needs to carry minimum __> = <?>= minimum number.<n>We can do it 5 or 6 (5/13 < 3<4) -> 5 is better <n>Since we know it takes 4 days total, we need (2/3) of 51 <n>__ = 2/3 X 51 = <?= 47

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? Choices:  A: cold hands B: wet floor C: health D: become wet E: dry skin<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:A: cold hands, not hot hands.<n><n>###

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would you put silverware once they've dried, but you're not ready to use them. Choices:  A: table B: restaurant C: cupboard D: kitchen E: sink<n><n>### Response:		Silverware should be put on A: table<n><n>### Rationale: A: table<n>The correct answer is A because that is where you would put silverware once it has dried but you're not too busy to use them yet.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What do you feel from playing football? Choices:  A: exhilaration B: pain C: death D: getting hurt E: get hurt<n><n>### Response:		<n>- If you get hurt when you play football, you experience pain.<n>- If you experience pain, you get hurt.<n>- If you get injured, you experience pain.

The driving distance is 67 miles, but there is tolls. The tolls are 40 cents per mile. How much money will you have to have to pay to reach your destination?<n><n>### Response to demo<n>A: The difference in the distance of the locations is 67 miles. The tolls paid is 40 cents x 67= 26.8 so 67-26.8= <<67-268=40.2>>40.2 miles distance<n>Deduct 40.2= <<40.2-40.2=0.0>>0<n>The tolls paid 40.2 cents subtract.0 = <<.0-0.0=0.0>>3<n><n>### You need 153.2 dollars to cover the cost of gas and tolls. What was your average speed if you drive 62 miles an hour?<n>### Demonition of above exercise<n>A: Your total cost is 153.4 subtract 67 is 86.3<n>Drive at 67 miles is 1 hour<n>86.3/67= <<86.3/2=116.6>>116.6<n>Miles an hour to drive is 116.6 miles an hour<n><n>#### 20<n><n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Input<n>Half of an octopus has eight limbs<n>### Response<n>An octopus is made up of eight limbs<n><n>You get 8 x 1 so it is the same as the octopus<n>#### 8<n><n>Answer: 8<n><n>### Input <n>The equation 74 + 4 =

Choices:  A: eyes B: biology laboratory C: shower stall D: old cheese E: decaying matter<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>### Instructions<n>If you answered anything other than C, you are correct. The options for each correct answer will appear when you submit your answer. Only one choice is correct.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where is a bald eagle safe? Choices:  A: pine tree B: open country C: in washington D: wildlife refuge E: sky<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following true or false questions.<n>### A:  What is the capital of washington?Answer: B (Sacramento, California)<n>B:  Did george Washington live in a cabin?Answer: C (No)<n>C:  The last bald eagle was seen recently in which city?Answer: E (New York City)<n>D:  Did washington own hundreds of slaves?Answer: E (No)<n><n><n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is a person chatting with friends likely hoping to accomplish? Choices:  A: gathering of information B: communication C: feel relaxed D: kill boredom E: social bonding<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>####A<n>\<n>In a time when we cannot meet our friends we have the easiest solutions through apps and software.<n><n>An example is WhatsApp! WhatsApp has made life easier to us because we can communicate instantly via video, audio and text.<n><n>We can even send a document or image in a group with our friends. In these circumstances we can also share our location or call each other.<n><n>Our chat is also end to end encrypted.<n><n>These are very useful features in today’s world because we can be connected easily with friends in a very long distance.<n><n>####B <n>\<n>In real life it can be a bit difficult because the communication in a group can be very slow. But through video we can also communicate easily with all our friends at once.<n><n>####C<n>\<n>The most important benefit from connecting with other people is that you can make new friends with the same interests.<n>####D<n>\<n>When you are bored you can also use WhatsApp to play games, and this can be a great way to kill boredom.<n><n>####E<n>\<n>Finally, WhatsApp is a great platform to create new social bonds.<n>Whenever an organization or a project needs to be organized quickly, WhatsApp and other apps like Zoom can be of great help.<n><n>### Output:<n>### Response:E<n>\<n>One of the benefits of chatting with friends is that we can create new social bonding.<n>There are many social bonding activities that one can do on WhatsApp like exchanging a movie with friends to see together.<n>\<n>Another example is playing games such as “Bridge” which helps to create new friends while staying home.<n>

Choices:  A: military base B: opera C: water fountain D: bus stop E: church<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n>Input: In a 37.25-ounce coffee can that was previously used to store nails, there were some old nails that were still in the can. How many old nails were there?<n>Rationales Choices: A is incorrect because nails are not ounces B is incorrect because the size of the can (37.25 oz) is not the same as the number of nails stored in the can (16) C is incorrect because when nails are moved from the can, they lose weight as the air around the can is released D is correct because nails are less than half the mass of the can. Therefore, at least 16 nails were inside the can. The can would not have been able to hold more than the original 16 nails because if there were 42 nails left inside the can, there would not be the same mass as what originally came from the can.<n>```<n>42 = 16 + mass<n>```<n>The sum of 16 + the mass of the can cannot exceed the can's mass.<n>#### 16<n>Answer: 16<n><n>### Input Choose the best alternative. Someone gave 6, 8, and 9 to 10 people, who are brothers and sisters. Then, this person gave the people money, not coins. How much did each person get?<n><n>### Response B<n><n>### Instructions<n>Choose among four options. Choices: A: 5, 6, and 10 B: 10, 15, and 20 C: 20, 30, and 40 D: 40, 50, and 60<n><n>### Rationales Choices:  D ←  If the numbers 6, 8 and 9 were distributed among 10 people, the sum of the numbers would exceed the people's total because 6 + 8 + 9 is greater than 10. <n><n>For example, if we give 6 to 6 people, the sum is 6 and 8 people, the sum is more than 10. If this person then gives each person money after giving the original 6, 8,or 9, then the sum of the money is less than

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		He went to his backpack to get new pencils. <n>Backpack(classification) <n><n>### Rationales:The student needed to get new pencil. <n>He went to his backback to get the new pencils.<n><n>### Response <n><n>### A: The student went to the store to get the new pneclis <n>Store(classification)<n><n>### Rationals <n>The student went to the store and he found the new pencils <n><n>### B: The student went to his classroom to get the pencils he was looking for <n>Classroom(classification)<n>He found the necpils on his desk<n><n>### Choice C: The student went to her teacher to ask for the pencils because he might not be able to find any new ones. <n>Teacher(Classification):<n><n>### The store(classification)

Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is D<n><n>#### E<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input:(A) Choose a number from 0 to 17.<n><n>### (B) Subtract each value from “5”.<n><n>### (C) Divide the remainder of each partial sum in (B) by 2.<n><n>### If we perform a vertical alignment in each line of the new arrangement of this number, the line with the least number of alignments, line “4”, has an alignment of 0. The sum of the alignments of the remaining lines is divisible by 3. The only multiple of 3 that can be obtained by performing this vertical alignment is “3”. Thus, we know that the remainder of the division of the number by 3 is “0”.<n><n>### Thus, the number of the first digit of the number is “4”<n><n>### To be continued...<n><n>Answer: <<To be continued...>><n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### To work on this exercise with the instructor, go to your [Repl.it](https://www.replit.com/hub?query=d%2527amond&type=&sort=popularity) account and click on the  “Repls” tab found at the top right of screen.<n>If you don’t have a Repl.it account, you can [create one for free]((https://www.repl.it/repls/k49/hub)#section1-2a72d015-f452-4376-8dde-dd505d6da80b<n><n>### Instructions for the exercise.<n><n>### To complete this exercise, your Replit account must have access to the “D’Amond” repository. You must navigate to the repository using the dropdown menu (top right of screen) and then create a branch named “1_introduction_to_Repl” (or similar name) off the branch “2_in-class_workshop” by clicking on “Branches” then on “+”.<n><n>### After creating this branch, you **must** change your current folder to your main folder by clicking on “Browse” above the input box of the “git status”

She had half a bagel.<n><n>Sabine had the pasta with meat, but not the pizza.<n><n>Susan had both of the items.<n><n>Sabina spent $2 on her breakfast, and Susan used a coupon for free ice cream and spent $0<n><n>Susan and Sabine each spent $4.70<n><n>Sabine spent $4.51<n><n>Sabina's breakfast was $4.7<n><n>Ali's pizza was $10 and her breakfast was $2<n><n>Therefore, in order from least expensive to most expensive, the trio's breakfasts were first Ali, Sabine, and Susan<n>Next, the trio'a $3.7 pizza was Sabine, then $10 Ali, and finally Susan's pasta with meat saucer ($4.71)<n><n>And finally, the trio''s outings:<n><n>Sabine was with Ali and Susan, who both paid $4.71<n><n>So, Sabine and Ali spent $2.71 at the same spot<n><n>Susan met with Susan alone and spent $4.71 there<n>So, Susan spent $2.75<n><n>Sabine and Ali spent $4.2 between them<n><n>When it was all said and done, Susan spent the most at $12.66.<n><n>#### 12.66<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input3:<n>This book is about a boy, David, and his new pet which he received from his grandfather this January. David was
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? Choices:  A: admiration B: applaud C: make reservations D: experience E: sleep<n><n>### Response:		the new play was the go-to performance of the year, and all the crowds would be standing in awe

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:How can one's views change after learning about science? Choices:  A: appreciation of nature B: become educated C: excitement D: increased knowledge E: see things differently<n><n>### Response:		How can one’s views change after learning science?<n><n>### Rationales:It becomes so exciting after learning science that we can see everything differently and this includes appreciation of nature as well. Science also makes us become educated and excited. After learning science, we become more knowledgeable about what we see and we can see things differently once we become more aware of the existence of things that have to do with science. We can appreciate nature more and this would surely increase our knowledge about everything around us. Being educated about science increases our knowledge of everything around us and we can use this increased knowledge to appreciate the nature that surrounds us as well.<n><n>### Rationale:A -> 1, B->3, C->2, D->4, E->5, F->6, G->7<n><n>### Answer:D: increased knowledge<n><n>### Rules:<n><n>- Please follow these three steps when writing the solution.<n>1. A truck leaves the first large city at 7 am. If it drives at a constant speed, what time will it arrive in the second large city? Choices A: 12 Noon B: 8 pm C: 5 pm D: 10 pm E: 12 pm<n><n>### Rational :<n>When a truck leaves the first city, the distance from the first city to the second city is 248 - 0 = <<248-0=248>>248 miles.<n>When the truck reaches the second city, the distance it traveled from the truck's starting point to the truck's arrival is 248.<n>If a truck drives at a constant speed of 50 MPH, in one hour, the truck traveled 50 * 60 = <<50 *60 = 300>>300 miles.<n>The total of the trucks' driven distance is 248 + 248 = <<248+248=500>>500 miles.<n>To complete the task, divide 500 by 300 miles and answer 500/300 which is 10/6 = <<10/6=

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:John ran out of pencils. Choices:  A: tennis elbow B: proffesional player C: exercise D: victory E: becoming tired<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A) Tennis Elbow:<n>The injury is caused by over-usage of the forearm muscles while holding, carrying and swinging the racquet. Tennis elbow may occur without overuse.<n><n>#### B) Professional Player:<n>Professional tennis players generally play an average of 5 to 10 hours a day. The 10 hours represents 5 hours of training to improve play, 3 hours of drilling, and 2 hours of matches.<n><n>#### C) Exercise:<n>Tennis has been shown to reduce the risk of cardio vascular disease, diabetes, obesity, and cancer and can reduce the effects of stress.<n><n>#### D) Victory:<n>Whatever your level, tennis can be the perfect workout for you. Tennis is probably the single most effective aerobic sport. A typical hour long game involves 1,400 kcal. You can burn up to 500 calories per hour, just from playing alone. You'll keep your heart rate up longer, which means more calories burned than with other sports. As in many other sports, it's possible to increase the intensity of a tennis game by running from one side of the court to the other.<n>#### E) Becoming Tired:<n>This one is about you. You can improve on your physical condition so that a 5, 7 or 10 hour game will be just great. When you are playing well physically you will enjoy your game more. This will result in a less stressful life.<n><n>### Input answer C (C = exercise)<n><n>#### C) Answer:E<n><n>### Explanation <n><n>#### 5<n>A: Tennis Elbow<n>B: Proffesional Player<n>C: Exercise<n>D: Victory<n>E: Becoming Tired<n><n>#### 5)C:Exercise<n><n>### Input Answer E(Exercise)<n><n>### Exercises:<n>If you choose Option A, your answer appears at the bottom of the page.<n>If you choose Option B, your answer appears in two boxes below.<n>If you choose C, your answer appears below the other answers in four boxes.<n>### Instructions<n>### Tasks<n>Demonstration<n>Input:What can years of playing tennis lessons lead to?

Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>Expedited<n>(2 x 70 x 12) % 5 + 2<n><n>### Output<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:In the given calculation, solve each of the following tasks as they are presented.<n><n>### Input Calculation:<n><n>### Solute:<n><n>### Response Summary:<n><n>### Demostration<n><n><n>### Input-<n><n>### Response<n>Answers the questions with the proper answers<n><n>### Input Instructions: Below is a task, which requires a single response.<n><n>Which of the following equations yields a solution of (0, -3)?<n><n>1/4x = 1/2 - 1<n><n>2x = 4<n><n>3x = 6<n><n>4x = 8<n><n>6x = 12<n><n>Answers the question with the proper answer<n><n>### Output-<n><n>### Demos<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>### Input Statement<n>Input: Solve each of the following tasks.<n>### Summary<n>### Demo<n>-In the first task, express x in terms of y and z.<n>-The first answer is the one that is in terms of y and x.<n>-<n><n>### Summary:<n><n><n>### Demo:<n><n>-In the first question, express x in terms on y.<n>-The second answer is the one that in terms of y and Z.<n>-<n><n>-In the second question, express z in terms of y.<n>-The first question is the one that is expressed in terms o fy.<n>-<n>### Instrucions: In the given calculation, solve the problems as they are presented. <n><n>### Input Task:<n>-In the first equation, 2x^2 + 3x - 2, find the positive value of x that solves for y. <n>-For the second equation, 2x + 2 = 2x^2 - 1, find the value of x that when added to what is found in the first equation satisfies both sides of the first equation.<n>-<n>## Summary:<n>-In the equation, 2x and y = 2, the value of x equals 1 because 1 + 1 = 2<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He is also not in a river because there is not enough space for him to flourish. Even though fish eat fish from the pet shop, a blowfish could not live in the pet shop since he would have to live with others.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What will you need to do to decide whether to be seeing artifacts? Choices:  A: learning B: painful memories C: thinking D: awe inspiring E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		<n>You will need to do thinking.

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:A lonely man committed suicide, why would he do that? Choices:  A: suffering B: he was happy C: avoid problems D: unhappy E: end pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:A lonely man commits suicide, why would she do that? Choices (A) suffering, (B) he was happy, (C) avoid problems, (D) unhappy, (E) the end of pain.<n><n>#### He is lonely because he was never happy<n>Rationales: (C) Avoid problems: why would a person who is suffering commit suicide? Therefore, the correct answer must be C) Avoid Problems because He's suffering.<n><n>#### He's miserable because he never finds people to talk to.<n><n>Rationales:<n>(A) suffering: why do you do that if you are happy?<n><n>[answer]<n>(B) He was happy: why would you commit suicide if you're happy?<n><n>#### He is unhappy.<n><n>Rational: (B) He is happy: a person commits suicide if he is unhappy.<n>#### He committed suicide because he can't suffer pain anymore.<n><n>Rationals:  (D) he is miserable because he can't handle the pain anymore.<n><n>\- He is miserable because he never met anyone to help.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: C<n><n><n>### Output:A) How many inches are in 10 years?<n>B) How many cents are in 10 dollars?<n><n>**Answer:**<n><n>B. 100<n><n><n>### Input-Output:The average age of a family is 25 years. The youngest child is ten years old. If the average age of a family includes the ten year old child. What is the average age of everyone else in the family?<n><n>Response<n>A) The average age of a family of 2 is 25/2 = 12.5.<n><n>B) Everyone else in the family includes the 10 year old child.<n><n>So the average age is 20 because the youngest in the family is ten and the average is 15.

Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		D :Huge<n><n>### Input : A teacher has five classes. Students in Class 1 were absent. All the other classes had at least twice as many students as Class 1. There were at least 25 students in each class. How many students were there in the five classes combined?<n><n>### Rationales: A: Since students in Class 1 were missing from the classes, we know there must have been at least 25 more students than in class 1.<n><n>B :There were at least twice the number of students who sat in those classes, so we know there are at least 50 students more than in class 1 if students in class 1 were absent.<n><n>C :We understand there are at least 25+25+25 students more than in class1 if Class 1 was empty!<n><n>D :The number of students in five classes is more than two classes.<n><n>E :The number of students is at least 50 plus the number of students in class 1 are absent from all classes.<n>#### 75<n>Answer: 75<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n>This is an example of a scenario. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:John was stuck in his house. Choices:  A: bounce the ball B: competition C: have fun D: race E: score points<n><n>### Response:		E: score points<n>### Rationales: The goal in basketball when scoring points is to have fun in the game. Scoring points is when points will be determined by the player’s performance. Bounce the ball may mean when the player throws the basketball from another player and catching it back, the objective is to score points in the game. A competition is when the player is against anyone else and they will compete for points but they can have fun too. A race is when they are competing against themselves and if a player wins the next round then they will score more points.<n>####  E<n>Answer: E<n>
